title: postcards lockdown britains oldest town coping coronavirus
story: Postcards From Lockdown is a new series looking at how communities across Britain are coping during the coronavirus pandemic. It will be published every day for five days on ‘Breathe it in’ reads the roadside signs welcoming visitors to Eastbourne. Retirees have long been enticed by the chalk-blue waters and bracing breeze of this south coast seaside town — England’s oldest, with a median age of 70.9-years-old. But in the age of Covid-19, that slogan has taken on an altogether more sinister air.Bill Watham and his wife, Ann, sit squarely in Eastbourne’s demographic bracket. Aged 70 and 69 respectively, both also have underlying health conditions which propel them to the top of the register of those deemed most at risk from the coronavirus.When the national lockdown was announced, the couple followed Government advice and holed up inside their red-brick semi on a quiet street in Eastbourne’s old town. Normally the pair, who don’t have a car, rely on online supermarket deliveries, but as panic buying ensued they weren’t able to secure a slot.Unable to leave home and with no family on hand to help, instead they resorted to eating whatever supplies they had left. When those had been used up, for five long days they survived only on porridge oats with water, and black tea.“We wouldn’t dream of asking anybody for help,” says Bill, a retired builder, standing a safe distance away at the threshold of his front door. Patting his stomach and trying to laugh away those frugal and frightening days, he estimates he lost 8lb in weight before help arrived. “Things happen in this world and you just get on with it,” he says. “That’s what we British do.”With Britain now on lockdown for the forseeable, today the  launches a new five-part series reporting on how we, as a nation, are coping. With coronavirus cases spreading out of the big cities and rising in the regions at a rapid rate, we are visiting towns and villages across the country as life changes beyond all recognition. As well as highlighting its tragic toll, we will be celebrating the stoicism of communities coming together in the face of the pandemic.Today marks 101 days since China first revealed to the World Health Organisation that a cluster of patients suffering from a mysterious pneumonia had been discovered in the city of Wuhan. Over the subsequent months, Covid-19 has spread at an astonishing rate, infecting more than 1.4m people across nearly every country on earth.The coronavirus washed up early on the south coast of Britain, in early February, with Brighton the first national cluster of infection. Eastbourne, roughly 20 miles along the coast, is deemed particularly vulnerable due to its elderly population and reliance on tourism.At the last count, there have been 95 known cases of coronavirus in East Sussex, and 14 deaths at East Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust hospitals, encompassing Eastbourne, Bexhill, Rye and St Leonards — though that figure does not include care homes, of which there are dozens in the town.The ramifications of the virus here will be profound. At the same time as its care industry and health facilities prepare to be pushed to the brink, Eastbourne’s tourist industry has collapsed.Sally and Andrew Kitchen are among those to lose their livelihoods overnight. The couple only took over the New Wilmington Hotel last July. A few weeks ago, the restaurant was declared best carvery in Eastbourne and Mother’s Day bookings flooded in. Then the lockdown was announced and, within 24 hours, three months of reservations evaporated.Sally, 48, says they have been forced to let 20 staff go and are waiting to hear back on an emergency loan requested under the terms of the government bail-out. “The potential revenue we’ve lost is huge,” she says.But in a matter of weeks, she and Andrew have managed to transform the business, using their suppliers and raiding the hotel chest freezers to provide emergency deliveries for the vulnerable, elderly and key workers across Eastbourne.Since setting up a fortnight ago, they have delivered to in excess of 100 customers — among them the Wathams. Bill grins as he recalls their first drop off after days of deprivation. “We had milk, jam and bananas,” he says. “All these things we took for granted have suddenly become such luxuries.”As I join Andrew Kitchen on his daily rounds, other grateful residents emerge from their homes to collect their boxes. Maggie and Rob Atkinson, both in their 70s, step tentatively outside their front door wearing marigolds and clutching antibacterial wipes to prevent any contamination.Before signing up to the deliveries, Maggie says, they had run so low on supplies that they had been forced to ration themselves to one piece of fruit and two slices of bread each a day.Another beneficiary is 90-year-old Barbara Granger, who has lived alone in her flat for the past 10 years. “Shopping has been a big problem for me because I don’t want to go to the supermarkets,” she says. “I very much appreciate the support.”Barbara is passing the lonely days of self-isolation reading and talking to family online. She will only turn the television on for the 1pm news, and again at 6pm. Last Sunday she, along with millions, watched the Queen’s speech. As someone whose formative teenage years were also spent during the Second World War, it resonated.“Then it was obviously a crisis, but also different because we knew who we were fighting,” she says. “I feel in a way this virus is more frightening than the war.”On the seafront, gentle waves lap the shingle beach and gulls wheel through the blue sky. The vista may remain unchanged, but any other semblance of normality has gone. The roads are largely deserted, though we spot several ambulances racing by.The council has – along with other local authorities - introduced restrictions on mourners attending funerals. One Eastbourne funeral director (who did not wish to be named) says he has already been required to handle the bodies of Covid victims while wearing full personal protective equipment (PPE).Care homes have closed their doors to visitors in an attempt to restrict the spread. Ian Turnbull, the manager of Sunrise Senior Living, says his care home’s 86 residents are on lockdown to all but essential visits. Even those on their deathbed are only allowed one family member by their side.Turnbull says the home has had several suspected cases, although they eventually transpired to be negative after testing by Public Health England. But he warns the testing system remains slow and inadequate. He has already heard of further suspected cases in other care homes in the town. “This is going to be a huge test for the care home sector,” he says.Earlier this week, Peter Kyle, the Labour MP for nearby Hove — which has about 30 care homes — said facilities were effectively being “converted into hospices” because of a lack of protective equipment and testing facilities. However Turnbull insists his staff have all the PPE they need.Georgina Kemp, 34, has spent 12 years working in the care sector in Eastbourne and is currently employed by the NHS, assisting with the physical rehabilitation of elderly patients in the community.In recent days, her role has been merged into an urgent crisis response unit. While Covid-19 has not yet engulfed the local hospitals and care homes to the extent of London, she says, they expect it to soon.“A lot of people are very scared,” she admits. For now, Eastbourne holds its breath.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: resurrection christ shows can find light even present darkness
story: A church parishioner watches a laptop inside Liverpool Parish Church (Our Lady and St Nicholas) in LiverpoolJesus’s victory over death tells us that we can have hope even in the face of unimaginable sorrowOne night, in 1499, the young Michelangelo, aged only 23, broke into the Chapel of Santa Petronilla and chiselled into his first masterpiece the words, “Michelangelo Buonarroti, Florentine, made this”.The masterpiece is, of course, the Pietà. He made this addition after hearing it said that a rival sculptor, Cristoforo Salari, was widely believed to be its creator, since Michelangelo himself was considered too young to have produced such a remarkable work of art. He later regretted his outburst of pride and never again added a personal signature to any piece of his work.The Pietà belongs to Good Friday. It depicts, with utter tenderness, the moment when the dead body of Jesus, taken down from the cross of his execution, is laid in the arms of Mary, his mother.The Pietà is a powerful image for all of us today, as we follow, with mounting dread, the daily roll-call of the number of people who have succumbed to death, attributed to the vicious work of the coronavirus. I cannot remember a time when such gruesome statistics were the headline of every news bulletin.The Pietà is an image of profound tragedy and sorrow. It speaks to the heartbreak of mothers in every time and place. Yet it does not match the sharpest of sorrow among us today.Today, mothers, daughters, sons and even the closest of friends are not able to embrace or even touch their loved ones in that final journey into death. They cannot care for their bodies. They must stand back from their lost one, and distance themselves even from each other, as the body is brought to its final resting place. What sorrow can compare with this? What scars this will leave, burdens to be carried for years to come.The eyes of faith struggle to pierce this darkness. If we are to cling to hope in this saddest of times, we need to follow closely in the footsteps of Jesus. He alone breaks through this darkness. He does so only because he is the Son of God, the Creator. If this is not so, then he, too, is helpless before the brutality of death.As God he conquers. Yet he is also one of us, fully one of our flesh. Without this human nature of Jesus, his victory would remain out of our reach. But, as wholly one of us, his victory is shared with his brothers and sisters, offered to the whole of our human family.The footsteps of Jesus that we follow today bring us to his death. Yet there are more, unseen footsteps that lead us further on. Only by following them do we come to realise the fullness of the victory he brings.From its beginnings, the Christian creed has proclaimed that after his death and before his appearances to his disciples, the victorious Jesus “descended into hell”. He entered the realms of every extreme darkness, bearing the cross, the weapon by which he had won victory. By means of his cross he broke open the tomb of death. Now he carries this cross, not to Golgotha, but into the presence of every forgotten soul and broken spirit. By the power of the cross, wielded by him as God, he belittles the death that defeats each of us.To us, his brothers and sisters, in every time and place, Jesus proclaims, “Arise O sleeper and rise from the dead and Christ will give you light!”The images of today are powerful: death coming in slow suffocation an inconsolable mother embracing her dead son the shattering of a dream and of a company of friends. The onset of total darkness. Such a day hardly deserves the title of Good Friday.Yet when we follow the invisible footsteps taken by Jesus after that cruel death, then a crack of light begins to open before us.This death is not the end this mother will receive her consolation this cross becomes the weapon of victory, breaking open the tomb and leading all who have died, reaching out for mercy in a triumphal procession. In this ine light, today becomes Good Friday.May this light uphold us in our dismay and guide us in our every word and deed.Cardinal Nichols is Archbishop of Westminster and author of The Glory of the Cross, published by SPCK and available on AmazonThe  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: uk lockdown extended full total restrictions
story: How likely is it that the Government will ban outdoor exercise?Coronavirus Article Bar with counter ..Coronavirus: the next 100 days - the future of UK, the economy and our healthForeign Secretary Dominic Raab, who has been deputising for Boris Johnson while he remains hospitalised, has warned that it was still too soon for ministers to begin lifting the strict social distancing rules introduced last month.Mr Raab said that the lockdown measures will have to stay in place until we've got the evidence that clearly shows we've moved beyond the peak when asked whether the Government had decided to extend the rules.Mr Raab also said: SAGE (the Government's Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies will meet next week to discuss the latest evidence and we'll keep the measures we put in place under review.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has warned outdoor exercise could be banned if iniduals continue to ignore social distancing rules. His comments follow reports some members of the public flouted social distancing rules last the weekend, which saw temperatures rise to 21 degrees and thousands flock to beaches and parks. Amid warnings that the Government could introduce tougher measures including a ban on exercise if social distancing rules are flouted, some local authorities have called for roadblocks to prevent people flooding to the area over the Bank Holiday.Police warned they were ready to take action against those who flout the coronavirus lockdown rules. Downing Street offered the Government's full backing to police forces seeking to enforce the restrictions over the holiday period.But there was a rebuke for Northamptonshire Chief Constable Nick Adderley after he suggested his force could mount road blocks and search shopping trolleys to check if people were going out to buy non-essential items.Home Secretary Priti Patel told talkRADIO: That is not appropriate, let me be clear on that. That is not the guidance.The Health Secretary, who has himself recently recovered from coronavirus, warned: “If you don't want us to have to take the step to ban exercise of all forms outside of your own home then you've got to follow the rules”. But how likely is it that the government will take this extreme step?Despite the warnings, Housing and Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick has confirmed there are no imminent plans to ramp up social distancing restrictions.Mr Jenrick has advised parks should remain open unless it was impossible to maintain social distancing. He also confirmed he had spoken to some local councils.This is their decision, but I have asked them to be very judicious in taking that step and only to do that where they feel it is impossible to maintain social distancing rules within their parks or open spaces, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.The minister also expressed his sympathies to those who relied on public parks as their only source of greenery. “It would be very unfortunate if we had to do so and make it harder for people, particularly people who live in flats in towns and cities, to get the exercise they deserve”. Mr Jenrick’s sentiments were shared by Councillor Gerald Vernon-Jackson chairman of the Local Government Association's culture, tourism and sport board. Police patrol Clissold Park in Stoke Newington to enforce the coronavirus lockdown.Councils know that parks are a lifeline for residents needing to get some exercise or fresh air and are great for physical and mental wellbeing.This is why councils want to keep parks open, but people need to follow the social distancing advice, otherwise councils will be reluctantly forced to close them as a last resort to help prevent the coronavirus spreading.While this weekend has seen the police ramp up their presence, senior police officers have called into question the practicality of enforcing a ban on outdoor exercise. Jayne Meir, Assistant Chief Constable of West Midlands Police, told the BBC’s Radio 4 Today programme: I can understand people are looking at further restrictions. It would be really difficult to police iniduals on a daily basis. Everybody has to take personal responsibility for this. It’s a collective responsibility to stay at home.As for now, the guidance remains unchanged  - exercise once a day, with members of your household and within areas local to you. Read more: How long do lockdowns last? Countries which acted fastest could be freed firstBelow are questions on the lockdown from our readers that the 's Front Bench Editor, Daniel Capurro, has answered. Our next Q&ampA will be on shopping and consumer rights and will take place at 1 p.m. on Monday. Send in your queries to yourstory@telegraph.Apologies to those of you who did not get an answer today. Our next Q&ampA will be at 1 p.m. on Monday and our Consumer Champion Katie Morley will be on hand to answer all of your question on shopping and consumer rights during the coronavirus crisis. Get your questions in for Katie by sending them to yourstory@telegraph. Here's our final question for today: I have been isolating for three weeks and so has my elderly mother (74). We are both fit and well and neither of us has developed or experienced symptoms of Covid-19 during the three weeks. I am worried about my mother's long term mental health and so wondered if I can go and live with her (with appropriate social distancing) for the next few months without putting her at risk? Could either of us be asymptomatic carriers?You should not be moving around during the lockdown and there is no way of knowing if you are an asymptomatic carrier without being tested. Also bear in mind that, were you to live with your mother, you would still have to keep your distance from her and limit the amount of time you spent in the same room. The Government guidelines on what to do if you live with a vulnerable person can be found here.Right, we've got time for two more. Here's our penultimate question: A reader emails to ask: Can I drive to pick my son up from uni, about 120 miles away? Would it be safer than him travelling by train?Dan: No. If your son can take public transport then driving is not an essential journey. In fact, if your son has somewhere to live at university then he should not be travelling home anyway.Another anonymous one now. A reader says: I own a property which I ordinarily  rent out long term. It is about 4 miles from my home. My tenants vacated 6 months ago and I have not been able to relet so am trying to sell. My insurance conditions state I must check the property once a week. Is that a necessary journey?Dan: You should speak to your insurer to find out if an exception can or has already been made for the lockdown. The situation you describe is not specifically included in the Government guidelines as a reason to travel.A very tricky scenario here for one  reader. Jonathan Crookes says: Three weeks ago my father in-law passed away in Scotland. Needing to attend the funeral, my wife and youngest daughter (two-years-old) travelled by train to the Highlands. Along with our eldest daughter (six-years-old) who still needed to attend school, I remained in Yorkshire to go to work.My wife had intended on staying a few days to attend to family matters before returning by train. But then the lockdown happened. For the last two weeks our family remains separated: My wife and youngest daughter staying with family in Scotland while I am with my eldest daughter at our family home. We’ve been diligently following the Government’s instructions but I think this is a valid case for travel, to bring my wife and daughter home and reunite the family. Are we allowed to travel to Scotland to collect my wife and daughter, and return straight to home?Here's what Dan has to say:That is a very difficult situation with no easy answer. If your family does travel back, they or your whole household consider self-isolating for two weeks once they arrive, to reduce the risk that they have brought the virus back with them. The Government is aware that they cannot issue guidelines for every single situation and they have said that, for example, children of separated parents can move between households. My main suggestion, however, is that you reconsider your aversion to public transport. By travelling there yourself, you are doubling the number of journeys being made and exposing yourself more. A concerned neighbour emails us to ask: Can my neighbour's have building work done still with two builders working on the job or are they not following the government's rules still ?From Dan: Yes. The Government does not want the construction industry to grind to a halt and the Business Secretary, Alok Sharma, has written to construction companies to make clear that their workers can continue to travel to work.It's our second fishing question of the day but there's a different answer for this one given the context.Brian Paterson says: Fly fishing is a solitary pastime. Am I allowed to partake of this as part of my exercise regime? I have to drive half an hour to get to the river but once there, I will not see any other people.Dan: No. It is not exercise and you have to drive to get there. The Government has been clear that it does not want people to drive anywhere to spend time outdoors. Issy List asks: Does going out solo on my kayak count as the one form of exercise a day? My house backs on to a broad and I am able to launch my kayak from here. Bearing in mind the broad is likely to be quiet (most boat hire centres are closed and tourists are restricted) and I can easily distance myself from other water users, is it acceptable for me to go out on my kayak? Here's what Dan has to say: British Canoeing has said that it “strongly recommends that all paddlesport activity should cease on rivers, waterways and coastal areas until further notice.” By the sounds of it, you are able to paddle without breaching any guidelines, but bear in mind the risk that you may have an accident and need medical treatment.Duncan Goodwin emails to say: A lot of allotment holders are over 70 but otherwise reasonably fit. Across the UK we grow huge amount of food for our families and friends and this is the time of year that we have to prepare the soil and set seeds for the year ahead.1. Is work on an allotment classified as exercise provided we maintain the recommended social distancing? 2. An hour a day probably is not enough this time of the year. Can we allotment holders be classified as food producers and ,so, for the next month or so, be able to do the odd half day? It's a good effort, Duncan, but I just don't think that's going to fly. Dan says: You can visit your allotment for your exercise, but you are not classified as food producers and there is no shortage of fresh fruit or vegetables in UK shops. The Government has not specified a time limit, although one hour has been suggested as a sensible amount of time. reader Jan Richards says: I have a large allotment on a very rural plot without close neighbours. In 'normal' circumstances, there are rarely more than a dozen of us present at the same time, spread broadly with at least 10 metres between each other.Providing we take precautions, such as wearing disposable gloves when opening and closing the single gate, for example... can I continue to go up there as my form of daily exercise?Dan says: Michael Gove has said that people can visit their allotment for their daily exercise. However, you should not be travelling for your exercise and must respect social distancing rules.There's no Wimbledon this year but are you allowed to play your own bit of tennis?Keen tennis player Michael Wiltshire says: My wife and I are both keen tennis players, so our question is whether members of the same household would be permitted to play tennis?  All the guidance relates to contact with people outside one’s own household so that any infection is not spread, but me playing singles with my wife, using our own balls and not entering the (closed) clubhouse, does not violate any of the guidelines, and does constitute an excellent form of exercise. I'm sorry, Michael. It's not good news.Dan says: No. The Lawn Tennis Association has ordered the closure of all tennis courts, saying in a statement that “ all tennis facilities and courts should be closed, and tennis coaching and activity should be put on hold with immediate effect.” Tennis has also been judged a social gathering under the Government’s guidelines.Via email, Andrew Knight asks: With the current lockdown due to coronavirus it is said we are still able to go out walking, exercising alone or with someone you live with is this correct? Where would we stand with going fishing to a river.There will be no socialising involved, just me and my son fresh air and a couple hours fishing?And here's Dan's verdict on the great fishing debate: You are permitted to be outside with members of your household, that is correct. However, you should not be travelling for exercise. If the river is a short walk away, then you may be ok to visit it, but not if you need to drive. That being said, fishing is not considered exercise and were you to be found by police, they would likely move you on.This is a popular one that we get asked almost every day.  reader Lesley Cahill says: With current government guidance allowing one form of exercise outside the home each day, is it permitted to leave home again on the same day for grocery shopping?I'm currently taking our dogs for a walk each day, observing social distancing, but then a couple of times a week I'm also driving (on my own I should add) to our local supermarket for shopping. Is this permissible? Dan: Yes, that is fine. The once a day limit applies to dog walks and exercise, while shopping trips should be kept as infrequent as possible.From Andrew Marshall: For many years there has been talk of a growing obesity crisis, the need to have fresh fruit and vegetables combined with daily exercise. Whilst the virus is impacting on normal life many garden centres are now closed with substantial numbers of plants and stock having to be destroyed: all at the time that many with gardens or allotments are starting to plant for the future harvest. This will also give the kids sat on their computers something to do over the next few weeks.The social distancing that is operating with supermarkets and food stores should be extended to garden centres. Not only will this save many businesses but also cover the items mentioned above.Could garden centres and allotments be reopened soon?Dan says: Garden centres are able to operate online and you can read our guide on how best to shop for gardening here. However, people should not be travelling to allotments. Time outdoors can be adequately sought in local parks or in private gardens, while fresh fruit and vegetables are readily available at supermarket.Another interesting one here looking at the idea of tighter restrictions.Daniel Valerio says: Are unnecessary jobs that you can’t do at home such as manufacturing or electronic goods warehouses going to close? Most of these places are still open and don’t intend to close with hundreds of people working everyday with very little safety measures, most of them are just not possible to follow the safety measures because of the amount of people that they have working.Dan: Unless the epidemic worsens or fails to decline under current measures, that is unlikely. The Government wants to keep as much of the economy running as possible, because unemployment and loss of wages are associated with long term health damage and a poorer country means a worse NHS. Alok Sharma, the Business Secretary, has made it clear that businesses can continue to remain open, even if they cannot meet full social distancing criteria, if they are not on the list of closed businesses and work cannot be done from home.It's the million dollar question!  reader Susannah Price says: I am extremely grateful that I am able to enjoy running outside, and I would hate to lose this freedom. I realise it is imperative that runners social distance themselves from others when running.But do you think running, alone or with members of your household, will be banned?Dan is cautious by he does have some good news for you, Susannah:The Government is very reluctant to limit people’s access to the outdoors. This is because they understand the importance of being able to exercise outside and worry that if measures are too extreme they could lead to a rebellion. That being said, if people fail to comply with the existing measures andor the virus continues to spread, it may become necessary.  The early signs, though, are that the current lockdown is having an effect.Another interesting one here via email. George Morris says: I am 79 and could be subject to various forms of restraint for 18 months. I am quite happy with this (I don't want to die) but would like to be allowed a short drive to somewhere remote so as to vary my daily cycle ride. Even better would be to be allowed to sail my boat. But the quite fatuous argument that I might have an accident and put additional strain on the emergency services has taken hold. Cycling (which is allowed) is far more likely to  finish up in A&ampE than a short drive into the country in a car or an hour's row round the bay in a boat. And far more dangerous than either is prolonged confinement to one's own home, the most dangerous place of all. Could short drives to remote locations be allowed?Dan says: The Government has been quite clear that, if possible, you must get your exercise near home. Wanting variety in your cycling is not a reason to drive somewhere. Our first question comes from Jane Hewitt via email. Jane says: Some people are taking walks or cycle rides covering quite a few miles, if this is the case, could someone like me take one shorter walk and one longer walk, but use the longer walk to buy essentials each day for six days? Here's what Dan Capurro, the editor of the 's Front Bench Newsletter, has to say: What other people choose to do should not impact whether you follow the rules or not. You should only leave the house once a day to exercise and, as infrequently as possible, to buy essentials. There is no specified distance or time, that is left up to iniduals, but the objective of the rules is to minimise your time outside your own home and your interactions with other people.Afternoon all! title: uks coronavirus epidemic may have seeded outside china new study
story: Britain’s coronavirus epidemic may have been seeded from Singapore, South Korea or Hong Kong - rather than China - the first genetic analysis of virus evolution suggests.Using ‘phylogenetic’ techniques that are usually reserved for tracing the origins of our early human ancestors, researchers at Cambridge University discovered that there have been three distinct variants of coronavirus since the disease emerged in Wuhan in December.Dubbed A, B and C, the three types have followed different paths throughout the globe, possibly because they have mutated to be better at infecting specific populationsVariant ‘A’ is the ancestral strain and is most closely related to the coronavirus found in bats and pangolins. Scientists believe the disease jumped into humans from one of the creatures at Wuhan Market.The second type ‘B’ - which is most common in mainland China - is derived from ‘A’, and separated by two mutations, while ‘C’ is in turn a ‘daughter’ of ‘B’.But interestingly it is type ‘C’ that initially infected Britain and Europe and that variant is not found in mainland China at all. In fact, it is most common in Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea suggesting that it spread to Europe from those regions. One English case also came directly from Australia.Geneticist Dr Peter Forster, the lead author from the University of Cambridge, said: “You have the ‘C’ type, which is not directly from China associated with Singapore and offshore East Asia and that’s where English cases come from. We know of an engineer visiting a Singapore conference and then returning via a chalet in The Alps, so that comes up in the network.“We usually use this analysis in tracing prehistoric human migrations, to allow you to see when they left Africa and populated the rest of the world, but nobody had thought to use it with a virus.“The viral network we have detailed is a snapshot of the early stages of an epidemic, before the evolutionary paths of Covid-19 become obscured by vast numbers of mutations. It’s like catching an incipient supernova in the act.”The technique has confirmed the importance of known infection routes, such as businessman Steve Walsh - the 53-year-old Brighton super-spreader who travelled to Britain from Singapore via The Alps in early February.Surprisingly, it appears that the countries who now seem to be doing the best at controlling the spread of the virus inside their own borders, are the ones from which the disease spread initially.Both Singapore and Hong Kong are yet to have a localised pandemic and are hopeful one might not happen. They have achieved containment through rigorous testing, contact tracing and localised quarantines. Likewise, despite recording more than 110,000 cases, Germany has seen just 2,349 deaths. But the new study shows that Singapore and Germany may have sparked the devastating outbreak in Italy, which has since spread to Britain.The analysis suggests that one of the earliest introductions of the virus into Italy came via the first documented German infection on January 27, and that another early Italian infection route was related to a “Singapore cluster”.Cases in Mexico, also appear to have spread from Italy, and in turn from the first German cluster in Munich - known as the Webasto case - which until now was believed to have been contained by German quarantine measures.After the first wave of infections from east Asia in Britain, a large number of new cases were imported by people who had been to ski resorts in Northern Italy during the half-term break. Northern Italy appears to have also been initially seeded by the German cluster.In contrast to Europe, the initial US outbreaks were of the ancestral ‘A’ variant.  Mutated versions of ‘A’ were seen in Americans reported to have lived in Wuhan, and a large number of A-type viruses were found in patients from the US and Australia.The A strain is largely absent across the Atlantic.The team used data from 160 virus genomes sampled from across the world between 24 December 2019 and 4 March 2020. Further work that has not yet been peer-reviewed using the analysis, suggests that the first infection occurred in humans somewhere between mid-September and early December. The research also shows that mutations in the virus appear to have sped up as it swept across the globe. The major Wuhan ‘B’ strain has not mutated much, which could mean it is immunologically or environmentally adapted to a large section of the East Asian population. In contrast, the other types appear to have speeded up the mutation rate, perhaps to adapt to changing populations.“If the virus wishes to infect someone from the US or Europe, these people have a different immunological response so you have predominantly type A and the English C type, so these are potentially to evade the immune response,” he said.“If you are in a very localised part of China then will meet with a homogeneous population who have come through a similar disease progression, but once you get outside then Europeans have gone through a different disease history and also possibly there is a more erse genetically erse population, so you get more mutations.”The team is keen to find out if certain strains are more aggressive than others, which could explain why some countries have much lower death rates. However researchers are struggling because countries like Spain and Germany have only sequenced a few dozen virus genomes and Italy fewer than 10.Dr Forster added: At the moment there are no clinical outcomes associated with the genomic sequences so we don’t know if the mutations are making some variants more lethal.“Phylogenetic network analysis has the potential to help identify undocumented COVID-19 infection sources, which can then be quarantined to contain further spread of the disease worldwide,” added Dr Forster.The study was published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS). More title: apollo 13 nasa anniversary moon what happened explained
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mission is remembered as perhaps Nasa's finest, and most desparate, hourExactly 50 years ago, Apollo 13 set off from Earth and for the Moon. Just a couple of days later came a blast and the words that would shock and fascinate the world:&nbspOK, Houston, we've had a problem here.Nasa is marking the anniversary of the mission it refers to as a successful failure, which represents one of its most high-profile disasters and its most famous miracles. It is a part of space history that is celebrated even today, with the story of the mission continuing to captivate the world.It was 11 April&nbspthat marked the day the astronauts blasted off on their way to the Moon, and 13 April that an oxygen tank explosion started the mission to save the astronauts from being stuck in space.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOn 17 April, nearly exactly six days after the mission began, the astronauts fell back through the Earth's atmsosphere and arrived safely back on Earth. It was an unlikely end to an unlucky mission.While it is now remembered as one of the most important moments in Nasa's history, the mission began in relative obscurity for a trip to the Moon. Apollo 11 had already managed to get to the lunar surface, and so what just a couple of years before was regarded as a near-impossibility was by that time relatively unexciting.Astronauts on screen from The Right Stuff to Apollo 13 and GravityBut hours later, television stations around the world were giving rolling updates on the mission's status, following closely as the astronauts and Nasa engineers back on Earth tried to save them from disaster.As well as being a relatively unwatched mission, the first couple of days of the journey were almost tediously straightforward. After two days of flight, one of the Nasa staff in mission control joked the astronauts that the spacecraft was in such good shape that they were bored to tears.Problems began on Apollo 13 when the astronauts were nearing the Moon and heard a bang and felt a shudder through their spacecraft. During what should have been a routine stir, one of the oxygen tanks on the spacecraft had burst and exploded.(After the mission was over, the explosion was traced back to overheating while the spacecraft was being tested on the ground, but there was no way to know that at the time.)The explosion also knocked out the fuel cells that should have been powering the spacecraft, and sent voltage in its circuits plunging. Engineers watching the mission from Mission Control saw the pressure in the damaged oxygen tank drop instantly.OK, Houston, we've had a problem here, said&nbspJack&nbspSwigert, the command module pilot who had actually joined the mission as a last-minute substitute for a colleague who had become sick just before the mission took off.Houston, we've had a problem, said Jim Lovell, the commander of Apollo 13.Almost immediately, it became clear that the astronauts would not be landing on the Moon, as planned. But that was a relatively unimportant challenge compared with the more pressing job of staying alive.In many ways, the explosion happened at the best possible time, and the astronauts would later say they considered themselves lucky. If it had happened earlier, they would have run out of power later, and the blast could have happened in lunar orbit or on the surface of the Moon.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. It has since been suggested that they may instead be formed by flowing sand NasaJPLUniversity of ArizonaMorning Aurora: Nasa astronaut Scott Kelly captured this photograph of the green lights of the aurora from the International Space Station in October 2015But the&nbspastronauts now still needed to travel&nbspthe 200,000 miles back to Earth, and do it without the oxygen or power they required for the journey. It would require them to slingshot around the Moon – coming frustratingly close to the surface they were supposed to land on – and then whip back around and float back home to Earth.In the meantime, mission control got to work putting together a rescue plan while the astronauts on board attempted to put out of their mind just how likely it was they would now die in space, something they say they never discussed.Flight controllers told the astronauts to shut down their command module and climb into Aquarius. That module was supposed to be the box that took the astronauts down to the lunar surface – but was refashioned into a lifeboat in an attempt to conserve power.Because it was never meant for so many people for so long, the lander was low on space. It was also filled with carbon dioxide, as the astronauts breathed inside their new, tiny spacecraft.One of the most famous breakthroughs came as engineers tried to find a way to fix that problem, by using the air purifiers from the now abandoned capsule in the lander. The two were the wrong shape to fit together – they were literally trying to fit a square canister into a round hole – but engineers back on Earth came up with a way of using various pieces of spacecraft to push the two together.Even once that was fixed, conditions inside the lander were miserable, without the energy for heating or other improvements to their conditions. They were stuck inside of a frigid box that was never meant to hold them, stuck&nbspfor days with little to do but wait and see if the various last-minute solutions to their desperate situation would actually work.(The astronauts have said they didn't argue during this time, despite the miserable conditions, and didn't talk about the possibility of getting stuck floating in space and waiting to die either Lovell wrote in his autobiography that they were too busy struggling for survival. He also denied that they had poison pills hidden away in case of becoming lost.)Eventually they arrived back near home for what is traditionally one of the most perilous parts of the journey: dropping back through Earth's atmosphere to come home. They had enough power to switch on the command module and wait as they went through the gruelling, hot ordeal of slamming back down to Earth.As they did, the communications blackout that comes from the extreme conditions of the Earth's atmosphere lingered for much longer than usual, leaving flight controllers in the dark as to whether the three astronauts and their hacked-together spacecraft had survived.But eventually they appeared in the air, the spacecraft being cradled by three parachutes as it fell through the sky and down to Earth. They were picked up and all three completed a journey whose legacy – one of inventiveness and luck that became mission control's greatest achievement – is still celebrated by Nasa today.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus farming jobs search record feed nation campaign
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Tens of thousands apply for agricultural work after warnings over fruit picker shortageMore than 30,000 people have applied for farming jobs after a campaign to “feed the nation” began two weeks ago.Jobs websites said they had seen record numbers of searches for farm work including fruit picking since farmers put out the call for extra staff.The UK faces an imminent shortage of labour, with many of the migrant workers who typically do seasonal farm work unable to travel from their home countries due to restrictions put in place during the coronavirus pandemic.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesConcordia, the charity tasked with filling the gap, said 30,000 people had expressed an interest and around 2,000 were currently being matched to roles on farms.Almost nine in 10 of those who have applied are UK citizens and less than one-third have a farming background. About half of applicants were seeking work after losing their livelihoods due to Covid-19, Concordia said.When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastThe latest round of jobs will start from the beginning of May when the UK’s soft fruit season begins with harvests of strawberries, raspberries and other summer fruits.Recruitment website Totaljobs has reported a record 50,000 searches for farm jobs last week. Searches for “fruit picker” and “farm worker” rose 330 per cent and 107 per cent respectively.The site has seen an 83 per cent jump in job applications for agricultural work over the past month.Steve Warnham of Totaljobs said he had noticed “a trend of workers who have been temporarily displaced due to Covid-19 who are now looking for roles they can take on in other sectors to keep Britain moving.”Other jobs designated as key by the government, including healthcare and logistics, have also seen a surge in interest.Mark Bridgeman, president of the Country Land and Business Association,&nbspsaid it was “wonderful news” that tens of thousands of people had come forward but warned that many more were needed.“We all know this is a deeply concerning period and we are all determined to do all we can to help the country through it. In order to do so, we must recognise that farmers’&nbspsupply of labour is in jeopardy,” he said.“A shortage of 80,000 workers is something we have never seen before. This is why we are calling for a ‘land army’ of workers to support farmers in feeding the country.”The campaign comes in the midst of one of the sharpest rises in unemployment on record, with more than 1 million new universal credit claims registered over the past three weeks despite government efforts to keep people in jobs by paying wages.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: uk economy gdp latest coronavirus ons data
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The UK economy contracted in February as poor weather impacted the construction sector, according to official statisticians.The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said UK GDP fell by 0.1 per cent during the month, as it slipped from 0.1 per cent growth in January.Economists had predicted that the economy would in fact grow by 0.1 per cent in February.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe ONS said the figures, which cover the period before the spread of coronavirus accelerated across the UK, reflected continued stagnation in the economy.Declining activity in the construction industry particularly hampered growth, with the sector reporting a 1.7 per cent decline in its GDP for February.Meanwhile, the services sector was flat, manufacturing grew by 0.5 per cent and the agriculture sector reported a 0.1 per cent decline for the month.The ONS also revealed that GDP grew by 0.1 per cent in the three months to February, on the back of growth in December and January.It said growth for the quarter was driven by a positive period for the service sector, although the industry is expected to show a sharp decline in the next set of figures, following the Government-mandated shutdown of pubs, bars and restaurants.Rob Kent-Smith, head of GDP at the ONS, said: “Today's figures show that in the three months to February, which was before the full effects of coronavirus took hold, the economy continued to show little to no growth.Most elements of the services sector grew, though manufacturing continued to decline.“Construction saw a notable fall in February, as wet weather and flooding hampered housebuilding.”Fran Boait, executive director of Positive Money, said: “There is a risk that as growth figures get worse, the government will be pressured to relax coronavirus prevention measures to get the economy going again, at the expense of lives.Office for National Statistics&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this title: coronavirus google park data location lockdown
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.While country is largely abiding by lockdown, warm weather could bring people outside, data suggestsMore people visited parks last weekend compared with two weeks ago, new data from Google shows.While the country has largely abided by lockdown – with visits to places such as shops and transport hubs falling – last weekend saw a rise in the number of people heading out to the park.Google is sharing location data gathered from people's phones in an attempt to understand how people respond to the coronavirus pandemic and the resulting lockdown. It has committed to make the data public as well as giving it to authorities, in the interest of transparency.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastPolice forces across the country have warned the public to stay at home over Easter, amid fears that a warm start to the weekend could see lockdown rules broken.The tech giant said it is using aggregated, anonymised data from products such as Google Maps for the analysis.The scheme protects people's privacy and will not include any personally identifiable information at any point, Google said.The data is traditionally used by Google for apps such as Maps to reveal when specific places of interest are busiest, as well as to revise driving routes when being used for navigation.Created with Sketch.Coronavirus: London on lockdown Show all 29Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A man walks down a deserted Camden High StreetGoodge Street Station is one of the many stations closed to help reduce the spreadAn empty street in the heart of ChinatownPeople in masks in Chinatown a day after the lockdownA near-empty Piccadilly Circus during the first week of lockdownSonja, my neighbour, who I photographed while taking a short walk. title: coronavirus quizzes internet online symptoms covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Questionnaires look like that are checking knowledge about pandemic – but actually gather unnecessary personal informationOnline coronavirus&nbspquizzes could be used to steal from people concerned about the disease, experts have warned.Questionnaires are being shared online that look like they are checking whether people know about the spread of the pandemic, but are in fact gathering personal information that could be used for fraudulent activity, according to the&nbspChartered Trading Standards Institute.The quizzes&nbspask&nbspfor details such as maiden names, family information, pets and contact details, including email addresses and telephone numbers, all bearing the hallmarks of a data harvesting operation commonly seen in financial fraud and identity theft, the institute warned.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe general public should be wary of online quizzes, especially those themed around the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, said Katherine Hart, lead officer at the CTSI.Many of them ask personal questions which may seem harmless at first, such as pet names however, scammers can harvest this data to create a full profile of the target.How technology and apps could allow the UK to leave lockdownSecurity questions for bank accounts and online passwords usually incorporate this kind of information.The public should remember that each little tid-bit of information shared online is available to fraudsters to pick up and assemble into a target profile.My advice is - think about what you are putting online, and who could potentially see this information.Over time this adds up, and you may find that you have placed much more information about yourself online than you first thought.It comes amid a spate of scams linked to the pandemic, as criminals seek to capitalise on people's fears.Created with Sketch.Coronavirus culture from rooftops, windows and balconies Show all 15Created with Sketch.Created with title: facebook quiet mode digital wellbeing your time app mobile iphone android coronavirus
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New feature part of a wide variety of responses to coronavirus pandemic, company saysFacebook has added a quiet mode to its app, in an attempt to make it less stressful.The company said it had rolled out the feature as part of a wider response to the coronavirus pandemic, to improve the wellbeing of its users.The quiet mode allows a user to turn off notifications from the mobile app, and can be turned on manually or at certain times of the day.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFacebook said the new feature should make it easier to limit the time spent online, as people are at home more than usual.“As we all adjust to new routines and staying home, setting boundaries for how you spend your time online can be helpful, the company wrote in an update to its coronavirus hub, where it has collated other responses including attempts to address widespread misinformation on the site.Facebook to try and build coronavirus 'heatmap'Whether it’s to help you focus on your family and friends, sleep without distraction or manage how you spend your time at home, we have tools that can help you find the right balance for how you use Facebook.The quiet mode follows other features such as tools that tracked how long people spend on the platform, in an attempt to help them not waste time on it. It is found in the same part of the site, known as Your Time On Facebook.Quiet mode will not only stop notifications coming up on your phone from the app – such as push alerts or the little numbers on the app icon – but will also stop notifications from appearing while you are inside the app.If a user attempts to open the app while quiet mode is engaged, they will be reminded that they had set it up so that they were not meant to be using the app.Created with Sketch.Gadget and tech news: In pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.125 Gun-toting humanoid robot sent into spaceRussia has launched a humanoid robot into space on a rocket bound for the International Space Station (ISS). title: coronavirus news latest easter bank holiday weekend new york infections
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The UK's coronavirus death toll has risen by more than 900&nbspover 24 hours, as police&nbspand politicians&nbspurge the public not to ignore lockdown rules during a&nbspEaster bank holiday weekend.Some forces have warned they may have to crack down harder on those flouting orders to stay indoors, after foreign secretary Dominic Raab urged people not to “ruin” the country’s progress on suppressing the Covid-19 outbreak.In the US, the latest coronavirus figures show New York alone - where infections have topped 159,000 - now has more cases of the virus than every other country in world.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesDeath toll rises by 866 in EnglandUK lockdown 'will be lifted for certain age groups and areas first'New York has more coronavirus cases than any nation outside USJohnson 'must take time before returning to No 10', says fatherHousing secretary told to 'explain&nbsplockdown&nbspbreaches or resign'Temperatures to hit 25C as UK spends Easter under lockdownPublic transport use remains lowIn the last week the use of public transport has remained at low levels, government figures have shown.The figures relate specifically to national rail and London transport networks.Nightingale hospitals to be built in Sunderland and ExeterTemporary Nightingale field hospitals will be established in Sunderland and Exeter.The news sites follow&nbspon from those elsewhere in the country including in East London, which began taking patients earlier this week after being set up in the space of two weeks.Matt Hancock - 'spreading the virus today means risking lives tomorrow'Mr Hancock closed his comments by calling on the public to remain at home ahead of the long warm Easter bank holiday.Spreading the virus today risks lives tomorrow and increases pressure on those who work in the NHS, he said.The more we all follow the rules the faster we can lift restrictions and get back to normal, he added.'A front door is better than any face mask' Hancock unveils PPE planThe health secretary has outlined the government's plan for personal protective equipment - including guidance ensuring only those who need PPE use it, and that it is only utilised when necessary for clinical reasons.Protective equipment should be reused when treating multiple patients, he added.He went on to call on the public at large to stay home as a form of protection.A&nbspfront door is better than any face mask, he added.Matt Hancock - 980 confirmed dead in hospitals across 24 hoursHealth secretary Matt Hancock has announced 940 people have passed away in a 24 hour period after contracting the virus.The figure is the highest single day increase in deaths of any European nation since the pandemic began.Nicola Sturgeon - too early to plan for the end of outbreakNicola Sturgeon has said it is too early for planning an end game for lifting coronavirus lockdown measures and returning society to normal.The First Minister said there is not enough evidence at this stage to set out a strategy to lift social isolation measures without risking disastrous effects in terms of the virus spreading.Speaking at the Scottish Government's daily briefing about coronavirus, national clinical director Jason Leitch added that the decisions would be made when the country reaches the downward curve of Covid-19 cases and deaths.Boris Johnson 'able to do short walks'A Downing Street spokesman has said&nbspBoris Johnson is able to do short walks between periods of rest while being treated for COVID-19 at St Thomas' hospital.More below:Ireland extends lockdown measuresIrish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has announced that the current restrictions on movement in Ireland will be extended beyond Easter Sunday to 5 May.Mr Varadkar added: We all know people who are suffering and grieving at this time, too many have died and sadly more will die and get sick before this is over.So today's message is that we cannot be complacent and we cannot lose focus.What we're doing is difficult, but it is making a difference and we have to keep going. We need to persevere and we need to maintain our discipline and resolve.The restrictions we introduced two weeks ago were set to expire on Sunday.Today, the expert recommendation is to extend them for further three weeks until Tuesday May 5.The Government has accepted this recommendation.&nbspCostume-makers swap Downton and Star Wars for hospital scrubsBritish costume-makers who normally dress actors in shows including Downton Abbey and&nbspGame of Thrones&nbsphave joined forces to make scrubs for medics fighting the coronavirus outbreak.Working from kitchens, sheds and attics across the country, the team of 150&nbspis churning out uniforms for returning medics and clinicians who do not normally wear them.Dulcie Scott, who most recently made couture dresses for Ruth Wilson in the BBC's adaptation of Philip Pullman's His Dark Materials, is helping lead the effort alongside a material buyer who once worked on a medical drama.She told Reuters:&nbspIt went way beyond anything I could have imagined.We have the most phenomenal, world-class network of costume-makers helping us.The&nbspgroup, which is calling itself Helping Dress Medics, launched a fundraising appeal&nbspfor £1,500 pounds to source materials and two weeks on&nbsphas raised more than £44,000. They now have&nbsp6,000 sets of scrubs in production.A curtain-maker has donated fabric, while the bosses of factories forced shut by the outbreak are working to cut the material.It feels brilliant and restores my faith in people and I think this is wonderful, Scott said. But also it's quite heartbreaking when you see what a need there is.Johnson will feel like he's been 'hit by several buses'Boris Johnson is likely to feel as if he has been hit by&nbspseveral&nbspbuses and will need time to recover from Covid-19, a virologist has said.Becoming ill enough to warrant a stay in intensive care leaves a patient weak and exhausted for a significant period of time, said Dr Chris Smith of the University of Cambridge.However, as the PM is not elderly,&nbspis in good health, and did not require a ventilator he is likely to be able to bounce back more quickly, Dr Smith said.He added: It'll still be a few weeks before he's feeling like his old self though.War-ravaged Yemen confirms first coronavirus caseYemen has reported its first case of the&nbspcoronavirus, raising fears of a catastrophe in a country where war has shattered health systems and spread hunger and disease.A 60-year-old Yemeni man was diagnosed in the southern oil-producing region of Hadhramout, an area controlled by Yemen's internationally recognised government, the supreme national emergency committee said.Spokesman Ali al-Walidi told a news conference the patient, who works in the small port of Ash Shihr, was in stable condition at a quarantine centre.A widespread&nbspoutbreak of Covid-19&nbsp&nbspwould be catastrophic in Yemen&nbspas the health status of at least half the population is very degraded and the country does not have sufficient supplies or facilities, UN&nbsphumanitarian coordinator Lise Grande told Reuters yesterday.&nbspThe news of the laboratory-confirmed first case came after a nationwide ceasefire prompted by the virus pandemic began this week.A Saudi-led coalition fighting Yemen's Houthi movement said it would halt military operations for two weeks, though the Houthis have yet to follow suit.Deaths in Scotland rise by 48A total of 495 patients have died in&nbspScotland&nbspafter testing positive for coronavirus, first minister&nbspNicola Sturgeon has announced.The figure is an increase of 48 from 447 on Thursday. title: liam payne one direction 10 year anniversary reunion
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.One Direction were put together&nbspon 'The X Factor’ in July 2010Liam Payne has teased a potential One Direction reunion in 2020 to celebrate the band’s 10th anniversary.The band were put together by Simon Cowell on The X Factor in 2010, going on to become one of the world’s biggest pop acts before going on hiatus in 2016.While Zayn Malik has been in less contact with his former bandmates since leaving in 2015,&nbspHarry Styles, Niall Horan, Louis Tomlinson and Payne have stayed in touch, with the “Strip That Down” singer telling The Sun that plans are underway for the group to commemorate their&nbspanniversary in July.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“We’ve got a 10-year anniversary coming up so we’ve all been speaking together a lot over the last few weeks which has been really nice,” he said.“To hear a lot of people’s voices and seeing old content and different things that we haven’t seen for a long time or never seen before, it’s very interesting.”A new Tiger King episode is coming to Netflix this weekendWill Ferrell and Kristen Wiig star in social distance soap operaRocky Horror star ‘disgusted’ by portrayal on RuPaul’s Drag RacePayne continued: “There’s a number of different things that we are all working on to try and make happen and people are forwarding emails around. But more than anything it’s just been a real good time for us to connect together again.”One Direction’s former members have all released solo music since leaving the band, with Liam admitting last year that he felt they needed at least two years to work on their own projects before staging a reunion.“I think at some point we will get back together,” he said. “I think we will, for sure. I don’t know when that is yet but, all I know is there is at least two years while everyone’s just released new music where you have to go and promo and do all of that.”The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: madonna pedro almodovar antonio banderas dinner party ana leza
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Director says Madonna told Banderas’&nbspthen-wife to ‘get lost’ after seating her at the far end of tablePedro Almodóvar has recounted an eyebrow-raising experience he had at a dinner party with Madonna and Antonio Banderas in 1990.The Spanish director shared the story with IndieWire as part of a series of&nbspessays he’s been writing about his past while under coronavirus lockdown.One year after Madonna invited him to visit the set of Dick Tracy, in which she co-starred with Warren Beatty and Al Pacino, the singer contacted him while in Madrid for her Blond Ambition tour.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAlmodóvar remembers that she was “interested in meeting” Banderas at a dinner party the actor was attending with his then-wife, Ana Leza.Upon arriving, Madonna was asked to be seated next to Pedro and Banderas, and is claimed to have requested that&nbspLeza&nbspsit at “the table furthest away” from them.Why does Hollywood so often soft pedal on its drunks?Can someone please put Killing Eve out of its misery?“At the end of the dinner,” Almodóvar&nbspwrote,&nbsp”Ana dared to get close to our table and told the ine blonde sarcastically, ‘I see you like my husband, it doesn’t surprise me, all women like him, but I don’t mind because I am very modern.’&nbspTo which Madonna replied: ‘Get lost.’”Almodóvar continued: “At some point during the dinner, Madonna told me, ‘Ask Antonio if he likes hitting women”’(I swear it was like that). I translated it for him. Antonio doesn’t say anything, he mumbles, and he pulls a face as if to say, ‘I am a Spanish gentleman and I’ll do whatever a lady asks me to do.’”He called this “the most amusing moment of the night”, and said he was coming forward with the story as footage her team filmed of the evening ended up being used for&nbspthe singer’s documentary, Madonna: Truth or Dare (also known as In Bed with Madonna), without Almodóvar’s permission.“I don’t mind if this seems like a settling of scores – if it had been the other way round,&nbspI would have taken such a hit in the form of a lawsuit I’d still be recovering from it. Madonna treated us like simpletons and I had to say it one day.”The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Created with Sketch.Pink supermoon lights up the night sky: In pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Biggest and brightest moon of the year so far was in full view on Tuesday nightPeople across the UK were drawn to their windows and gardens on Tuesday evening as&nbspa pink supermoon&nbsprose over the night sky.Many&nbspgrabbed their cameras and smartphones to try to record the lunar light show, which saw the biggest and brightest moon of the year so far.Twitter users posted their attempts to capture the view&nbspand to share their delight at the “amazing” and “beautiful” phenomenon.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesDespite its name, there is not any noticeable colour difference to the full moon, which was set to reach its peak at 3:55am on Wednesday.The pink supermoon name is a northern Native American reference to an early-blooming wildflower, which is first seen in the US and Canada at the beginning of spring.Nasa asks for applications to go to the MoonIn some other cultures, the pink moon is known as the sprouting grass moon, the egg moon, and the fish moon.One Twitter user wrote: “If anyone needs a moment of calm, take a look at the moon right now.”The moon&nbspappeared up to 14 per cent&nbspbigger and 30 per cent brighter than usual in the sky as it reached&nbspits closest point to Earth, known as its perigee.April's supermoon is the third of the year, and largest so far, following the worm moon on 9 March.The next full moon is referred to as the Flower Moon, which takes place on 7 May.Additional reporting by Press AssociationBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: supermoon how to take photo full moon space photography best tips
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Nasa photographers give their tips on taking the best photos of the moon and spaceThe April 2020 supermoon&nbspwill be the biggest and brightest of 2020 as its elliptical orbit brings it closer to the Earth in more than a year.On 7-8 April, the full moon will reach as close as 356,907km (221,772 miles), and will appear most impressive at moonrise on Tuesday and moonset on Wednesday.Clear skies in the UK, combined with unusually low air pollution due to the coronavirus lockdown, make it one of the best opportunities in years to view the rare celestial phenomenon. Here’s how to take the perfect picture of it:Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesUse a landmark to get perspectiveEveryone will be taking pictures of the supermoon by itself, but some of the best pictures show the moon next to a land mark or trees and houses, which is what helps to give the picture “a sense of place”, says Nasa’s senior photographer, Bill Ingalls. “Think of how to be creative – that means tying it into some land-based object. It can be a local landmark or anything to give your photo a sense of place.”Created with Sketch.9 best images of the 2016 supermoon Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with with getting a perfect picture of the supermoon if you have time to plan it. You can look up the best monuments or statues in your area to photograph the image of the moon against, like Mr Ingalls does in Washington D.C., where he lives. “It means doing a lot of homework. I use Google Maps and other apps – even a compass – to plan where to get just the right angle at the right time,” he told Nasa.Use an app to find the moonUnless you're an astronomer, the best way to know where the moon will rise or set is to use a app on your smartphone to locate it. There are several free or cheap options you can choose from, each using your phone's inbuilt accelerometer to know which way you're facing.The apps can also tell you what phase the moon is in, while some even give other celestial details, like the location of planets and star constellations. Decent options for iOS and Android devices include Star Chart, Sky Safari and Skyview.Get the right exposureIf you’re taking a picture on your camera, control the light balance by first tapping the screen where the moon appears to get the camera to focus on the object before dragging your finger up and down to play with the exposure. “You’ll usually want to drag it down for underexposure to be sure you have all the highlight detail,” National Geographic photographer Michael Christopher Brown said.Use a tripod for your camera or rest your phone on a solid surfaceDavid Reneke, an astronomer and writer for Australian science magazine told ABC.net that if you’re using an SLR or DSLR then it’s important to play with aperture settings on your camera to photograph the supermoon, but that using a tripod is essential.It’s worth using a tripod for taking pictures with a smartphone too, as any camera shake can compromise the quality of the pictures – but if you don’t have one to hand you can simply rest your phone on a window ledge.For older smartphones that use a digital zoom rather than an optical zoom, it’s generally best not to use the zoom as it could compromise the quality of the image. Instead, take the picture and then crop it.Newer phones like the Huawei P30 and P40 series feature incredible zoom capabilities that can take detailed pictures of far away objects. Other cameras come with special features to improve pictures of the night sky, such as the Google Pixel 4’s Astro mode.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus help the hungry food campaign bishop auckland county durham
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘It’s been crazy and heartbreaking to see how much people are struggling,’ says volunteer dropping off freshly cooked meals in County DurhamThe coronavirus pandemic has forced many food banks hit by a drop in donations and volunteers to close. Yet some arts charities have switched gears and stepped in to help, delivering emergency food packages to people in desperate need.The Auckland Project – an organisation delivering cultural and education programmes in the northeast town of Bishop Auckland – is now leading a huge emergency food operation to deliver supplies to vulnerable people in County Durham.The Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign has been supporting the work going on across the UK to ensure that everyone has enough to eat during the outbreak, backed by figures such as London mayor&nbspSadiq Khan, Labour MP&nbspJess Phillips&nbspand TV cook&nbspNigella Lawson.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Auckland Project is an impressive example of how small groups are adapting to the crisis. Based at Auckland Castle, the kitchen staff at the visitor cafe are now cooking 500 fresh meals a day. More&nbspthan 10,000 of the frozen meals have been dropped off at homes in the area over the past few weeks.“We knew a big section of the community would be hit hard by this, so we felt getting food out to those in need was the best way to help,” said Liz Fisher, one of the directors at the project. “It means big changes, but the staff wanted to do all they could – they really stepped up.”How to support our campaignThe Auckland Project’s team of 17 staff and volunteers has been busy working in the kitchen, preparing dishes such as cottage pie, lasagne, mince and dumplings and carrot cake for distribution.There is a move to grow food locally, too. Two acres of the castle’s walled garden has now been set aside for planting potatoes, beans, leeks, cabbages and asparagus.“Hopefully we can start getting the food we grow here into our meals, and possibly even have a celebration dinner once we get past the crisis,” said Ms Fisher.The charity has teamed up with the South Durham Enterprise agency and another local charity called Health Express to work out which iniduals and families need support.Chris Bowron – owner of The Miners Arms on the outskirts of Bishop Auckland – is also part of the emergency food drive. His closed-up pub acts a distribution hub for the local “mutual aid” group, and Mr Bowron and a team of volunteer drivers deliver around 150 frozen meals from The Auckland Project each day.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists.
