title: home secretary priti patel blasts top cop snoop shopping coronavirus lockdown
story: Priti, , made the comments while speaking to The Sun’s Executive Editor Dan Wootton on his talkRADIO Drivetime show this afternoon.She came on air just minutes after leaving today’s emergency Cobra meeting and gave her first and only interview since the lockdown began.When asked about the comments made by Northamptonshire’s Chief Constable Nick Adderley in a press conference, where he warned the public officers would stop and search their trolleysthey failed to adhere to the current lockdown measures, she said:  “That is not appropriate, let me be clear about that.“I work with the police and leadership every day of the week and have been since this crisis and leading up to this crisis“That is not the guidance or the measures we have been adopting thus far.”She went on to ask the public to adhere to the lockdown over the Easter weekend and praised the public for their reaction to measures put in place by the government so far.Priti said: “I think what we should say about this weekend in particular, the weather is going to be good, it is Easter. We all need to take responsibility here. This is not about overreach.“We had scurrilous stories a few weeks ago about officers snooping through baskets and removing Easter eggs and that became a trading standards issue.“That is not what the police are there to do. As I said the police are there for public order.“I will be very candid, not everyone will get this right. It will take a few weeks to have these measures bed in.“We want our public spaces to be respected and utilised in the right way.“This is not about heavy handed law enforcement. I pay credit to the police, and the majority of the British public – these are extraordinary times.“But the fact of the matter is,you’re having a party or having a mass gathering do not be surprisedthe police come up and ask you to stop.“The police are using a common sense approach. Enforcement will always be used as a last resort.”In her interview Priti went on to accuse Yvette Cooper of playing politics and insisted she had given the Labour MP a date to appear in front of the Home Affairs Select Committee.When askedshe was concernedYvette wanted to publicly quiz her over bullying allegations made before the start of the crisis, and whether she wanted to deny those on the record, Priti answered: “This is not what this is about at all.“I have offered the chair of the committee regular briefings throughout this pandemic, including access to classied material.“It is disappointing to see this at the time of the crisis when I have already offered a date. There is politicking going on.“When you look at the work of the Home Office during this pandemic, by making  calls free of charge, through the extension of NHS visas, to ious things we’ve been doing across fraud, cyber, national security, policing every single day and the help we are giving to the front line – a lot of that is self evident.“I quite frankly think it is politicking, when we have given access to the entire committee to the department, to myself in terms of another date.“I just think it’s politics basically.”Priti also went on to give up an update about Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who on Thursday night was moved to a ward after spending three nights in intensive care at St Thomas Hospital in London.She said: “He is doing well from what we’re hearing, but we should take great heart that he is in the care of the NHS. We are rooting for him. He is really great, we just want him to get well now.”“I spoke to him last week, around the last cabinet meeting and then it was clear he was unwell and that he needed rest and recoup.“He has been working flat out leading us through this, we need to give him the time and space to recover. We wish him well.”During the interview Priti went on to say the government were considering new measures to help domestic violence victims and confirmed she would be laying out the plans next week.She said of domestic abuse victims on lockdown with their partners: “This is an absolute priority for the police.“I have spent a lot of time speaking to charities and third parties and also the victims commissioner.“There is a lot of work taking place, I have already been resourcing this area. But of course the longer the pandemic continues there will be all sorts of issues around people staying at home and victims of abuse being with their perpetrators. We are finding other ways we can give them the support but also ways we can do more in prevention and protection.“I have been doing a lot of work with this sector and charities about how we can improve our response and get resources out there on the front line in dferent ways. I will be outlining these in the days to come but I can assure you that when it comes to vulnerable children and domestic abuse victims there is a lot of cross government work taking place.”Priti also discussed the increased threats to the public from online fraudsters since the beginning of the pandemic.She said: “I spend every day looking at threats and risks to homeland security. We are seeing all sorts of things but we are especially seeing new threats from online harms and threats in terms of cyber fraud and breaches of cyber security.“As a result there are more protective measures we are undertaking. For example we are seeing a lot more financial fraud online. We are seeing more activity in the space and sphere on online harms particularly around vulnerable people and children and I am working with the National Crime Agency on this right now.“The wrong types of people, perpetrators of crime are at home and are spending a lot of time on the internet, so a lot of work is taking place across the whole of law enforcement, the crime agency, our security and intelligence services as well.“We absolutely are on it.“I will be very candid, they themselves are facing challenges themselves in terms of how they are working.“Across the policing and intelligence community they are incredible in what they are doing but the intelligence they are being fed in – we are actually seeing less crime but they are actually dealing with more crime because they are able to see more crime, perhaps in a way in which they haven’t been able to previously.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: change health conditions lockdown twice
story: A NEW change in lockdown rules means people with certain health conditions can now leave home twice a day.It comes after a legal discussion between Public Health England and a firm representing two autistic children who need to leave twice for their health.Now those with health conditions which require them to leave home more than once a day will be allowed to do so.The updated guidance now reads: You can leave your home for medical need.If youhave a specic health condition that requires you to leave the home to maintain your health - includingthat involves travel beyond your local area - then you can do so.This could, for example, include where iniduals with learning disabilities or autism require specic exercise in an open space two or three times each day - ideally in line with a care plan agreed with a medical professional.Before the change Brits were only allowed to leave their homes once a day and not allowed to travel signicant distances.People are only allowed to leave their home for the following very limited purposes:It comes after Birdmans LLP law firm was asked to help by two families with children on the autistic spectrum.The firm explained: One child in particular is deliberately taken to a quiet location that is not local to them, because of their particular needs and where there is a far more limited risk of infectionthanhe were to remain in an urban environment.It was submitted that adults and children with certain health conditionswere disproportionately impacted by the inflexible policy which required everyone to only leave the house for exercise once per day, and which was therefore unlawful and discriminatory.After the change, a spokesperson for the Cabinet Office said: “The single most important action we can all take, in fighting coronavirus, is to stay at home in order to save lives, protect the vulnerable and protect the NHS.“We understand that this will be more dficult for some, that’s why we claried the guidance regarding the needs of those with specic health conditions such as learning disabilities or autism.It comes as police called for further lockdown powers.At least five chief constables support bans on long car journeys and outdoor exercise as they gear up for a sunny Easter weekend.They are urging ministers to give them the powers they need to keep lockdown enforced over Easter.People have been ignoring social distancing rules and flocking to parks and beaches across the country as the weather warms up.Health Secretary Matt Hancock warned last weekend restrictions would have to be tightened  people continued to ignore the lockdown.A Government evaluation of lockdown powers in England is considering tougher restrictions such as those in force in Wales - including restricting exercise to once a day.Before falling ill, Boris Johnson pledged to review the lockdown on Easter Monday, April  — three weeks after it began on March .But Downing Street is seriously concerned that people may defy advice and head out to enjoy the C bank holiday sunshine.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: uk lockdown dominic raab too early
story: IT IS too early to lt the coronvirus lockdown measures right now and Brits must stay home this Easter bank holiday weekend, Dominic Raab said tonight.The Foreign Secretary, who is standing in for Boris while hes in hospital, apologised to the nation that they will be unable to see their families this weekend as part of the fight to stop the virus.And he took the chance to thank everyone - including NHS staff on the front line - for their hard work so far in savings lives.He told the public ahead of a sunny weekend: It is too early to lt the measures we have put in place.We must stick to the plan and continue to be guided by the science.Thank you for your sacrice but we are not done yet. We must keep going.No easing of the lockdown will happen until at least the end of next week, he said - but the strict measures will likely continue for even longer.Professor Chris Whitty said he would expect the number of deaths to continue rising for at least two weeks past when the number of people in intensive care starts to flatten off, showing the peak is still some time away.Mr Raab urged anyone considering breaking the rules in the coming days to think very hard about those who were on the front line battling the virus.He would usually be spending the Easter bank holiday weekend with his family but admitted we just cant do those sorts of things, and I am really sorry about that.As a country we need to be united in this mission.We have to keep it up.Mr Raab admitted tonight that he hasnt spoken to Boris Johnson since he went into hospital, and was rushed into intensive care on Monday evening.He said it was important to give him time to rest and recover, and stressed I’ve got all the authority I need to make the relevant decisions.That will include huge choices on extending the lockdown next week,the PM isnt well enough by then.The news came as:The Government is continuing to gather all the data on how the lockdown is working so far before making any firm calls, he said.The early signs suggest that they are having an impact, but its too early to say that conclusively, he added.We will be guided by the science at all times.We dont expect to be able to say more on this until the end of next week.The measures will have to stay in place until we have the evidence that clearly shows weve moved beyond the peak.Mr Raab said the PM was still in intensive care but continues to make positive steps forward, and he is in good spirits.He is still not in need of a ventilator and is able to breathe without assistance.Boris is said to be sitting up in bed and talking to the NHS staff who are caring for him too.It’s expected that the lockdown will be extended title: inside worlds last cannibal tribes human flesh rituals
story: The tribes exist in some of the remotest corners of the world, and can be seen living as they have done for thousands of years.The Aghori monks of India use herbal drugs, alcohol, and meditation as well as human flesh in their rituals.The group reportedly obtain corpses from the Ganges River, downstream from where they are set afloat by relatives unable to afford a cremation or burial.In , US broadcast Reza Aslan met the a number of the monks and was filmed eating human brain while taking part in a ritual.Freelance photographer Tamara Merino, who also spent time with the group, said: “They are people that have so much love and respect for people, animals and nature.It’s just as beautul as any other religion is.”The Asmat people are native to New Guinea Island, and are thought to have traditionally hunted their enemies and used their skulls in cooking.Journalist Carl Hoffman wrote of the group: “They shook the brains out onto the leaf of a palm, scraped inside the skull with a kne to get every last bite, then mixed the mass with sago, wrapped the leaf up, and roasted it on the fire.The group is thought to have been responsible for the  death of Michael Rockefeller, a member of the Rockefeller dynasty and fth son of future vice president Nelson Rockefeller.Rockefeller was on an expedition in the New Guinea region when the boat in which he was travelling capsized.He left a companion drting with the boat and swam  miles to shore, but is thought to have been killed by the Asmat after he arrived.The Korowai are a tribe that live in West Papau in the western half of New Guinea Island.They live mostly in dense areas of rainforest, and remain isolated from much of modern world.Italian photojournalist Gianlunca Chiodini said of several days he spent with the group: “I really wanted to visit one of the most genuine and remote tribes in the world.“The Korowai live in the heart of the rainforest, where they’re not yet exposed to the modern world, so they still maintain many of their age-old traditions.”The group reportedly continue to practice witchcraft and to eat human flesh, though has been speculation that members have encouraged the stories to promote interest from the outside world.The Sentinelese are a tribe that live on North Sentinel, an island off the eastern coast of India, and are among the last truly uncontacted people in the world.They speak a unique language and have had very limited contact with the outside world.They have been described as a Stone Age tribe, and are believed to have lived on the island in isolation for up to , years.In , the group killed US missionary John Allen Chau with bows and arrows after he landed on the island as part of an attempt to convert its inhabitants to Christianity.Speaking at the time about planned attempt to recover Chaus body, Survival Internationals Director Stephen Corry said: The risk [to the Sentinelese] of a deadly epidemic of flu, measles, or other outside disease is very real, and increases with every contact.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: babies buggies breathe polluted air
story: Researchers simulated  school drop-off and pick-up trips — walking around . miles between am and am, and pm to pm.Three styles of buggy were used in Guildford, Surrey — single forward-facing and rear-­facing, and a two-tier type.They found that on average — regardless of the pushchair type — tots could be breathing  per cent more harmful pollutants than their parents.And with the double pushchair, the child at the bottom faced up to  per cent higher­ ­ex­posure to pollutants than the one in the top seat.The team from University of ­Surrey’s Global Centre for Clean Air Research found that pushchair covers reduced the concentration of small-sized pollutant par­ticles by as much as  per cent.Its Professor Prashant Kumar said: “For parents, nothing is more important than the health of our children.Covers and upping the buggy heights appears to have shielded children from an appreciable amount of pollution under certain conditions.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Harmony Dawes, , said her dad had burst into her room during the night to tell her she had matched five numbers to the Set for Le draw on March .When Harmony, of Brighton, woke the next day, she told her dad of the “dream” at breakfast.Ms Dawes, from Brighton, East Sussex, said: Im not sure how Id forgotten dad bursting into my room in the early hours of Friday morning screaming that Id won the lottery but it really felt like a dream.In fact, even now its been confirmed, it still feels like a dream.Every time I think about my win Im waiting for someone to tell me its one big joke, its ridiculous, this sort of thing doesnt happen to people like me. story: A TEACHER has been hailed a hero for walking more than five miles a day to deliver packed lunches to disadvantaged children during the coronavirus pandemic.Zane Powles has handed out  lunches at a safe distance until the sandwich bag is picked up.Zane, who works at Western Primary School in Grimsby, Lincolnshire, said: Its about making sure vulnerable kids get at least one decent meal.People are risking their lives on the front line or delivering medicines as a volunteer, and Im doing this because its the right thing to do to help where I can.Its important that Im doing my bit title: boy first coronavirus case remote amazon tribes
story: A -YEAR-OLD has become the first coronavirus case in a remote Amazon tribe amid fears the deadly bug could wipe out native communities.The teenager, from the Yanomami tribe along the Brazilian-Venezuelan border, was taken to intensive care with Covid- symptoms.The lad was admitted after suffering with shortness of breath, chest pain, a sore throat and fever on April Although he initially tested negative, a second examination proved positive.According to the countrys Globo newspaper, the boy travelled back to his reserve on the banks of the Mucajaí River after his school classes were suspended due to Brazils outbreak.He has since been taken to the General Hospital of Roraima in Brazils northernmost state.The Yanomami tribe is believed to be the largest indigenous people in Brazil and occupies over  villages across .million acres.Seven tribesmen have reportedly contracted the deadly virus across the Amazon states of Pará, Amazonas and Roraima.Brazils medical experts now fear that the countrys indigenous communities face an unprecedented crisis.Tribal elders are most vulnerable to the lethal effects of the virus, and their deaths would have a signicant impact on the tribes hierarchy and wisdom passed down through generations.To tackle the outbreak, members of some communities are reportedly breaking off into smaller groups equipped with hunting supplies to isolate themselves.Federal University of São Paulo researcher Dr Sofia Mendonça told BBC News: There is an incredible risk of the virus spreading across the native communities and wiping them out.Everyone gets sick, and you lose all the old people, their wisdom and social organization. Its chaos.There are currently , confirmed cases of coronavirus in Brazil and  deaths.Earlier this month an indigenous woman in a village deep in the Amazon rainforest also contracted the novel coronavirus, the first case reported among Brazils more than  tribes, the Health Ministrys indigenous health service Sesai said.The -year-old woman from the Kokama tribe tested positive for the virus in the district of Santo Antonio, near the border with Colombia some  kmup the Amazon river from the state capital Manaus.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus nurse reveals ppe sores
story: Aimée Goold, from East Retford, Notts, described working at UK’s covid- frontline as going “through hell” in an emotional Facebook post.The nurse, who works at Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, shared a picture of her face covered in red marks and blotches from hours of working in the protective mask.She also described the long shts NHS workers are pulling – revealing how she had worked  hours over the last  days.Amiee posted thre status to stop people from going out and flouting lockdown rules over the Easter weekend.She wrote: “When youre tempted to go out this Easter, remember this face.“This is the face going through hell.“This is the face full of pressure damage from wearing PPE for almost  hours a day.“This is the face of someone who hasnt seen their own family for nearly a month.“This is the face of someone who holds your dying family members hand, so theyre never alone.”Amiee finished her post by saying: “This is the face of an ICU nurse that is begging you: to stay inside, protect us, protect the NHS and help us save lives.”Amiees message comes as the government has announced it was launching a publicity drive over the bank holiday weekend to get the public to follow the lockdown guidelines over East weekend.Concerning figures show the number of hospital patients in the UK who had died after testing positive for Covid- had risen to , as of pm on Wednesday - an increase of  on the previous day.At the daily No  press conference, Mr Raab acknowledged that it was hard for to stay indoors over Easter, but he urged them to show restraint amid signs the measures were having an impact.He said: The deaths are still rising and we havent yet reached the peak of the virus. So its still too early to lt the measures that we put in place.We must stick to the plan and we must continue to be guided by the science.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Governments chief scientic adviser, said measures were breaking transmission of the disease with signs of a flattening off in the numbers of new cases and hospital admissions.However, he warned the numbers of deaths would continue to rise for a few weeks and that it was too soon to relax social-distancing.It is incredibly important that we continue to do what we are doing, he said.The chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said that while the numbers admitted to intensive care had been doubling every three days, that had now slowed.This is really now becoming not quite flat, but the doubling time is now six or more days in almost everywhere in the country and extending in time, he said.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: private jet super rich lockdown france
story: Seven men in their s and s and three women in their s arrived at Marseille-Provence airport last Saturday and were immediately intercepted by local police.The organiser of the trip – a Croatian businessman working in the UK – had booked the jet and helicopters to take everybody to the rented villa.A police source told the BFM news outlet: They had planned to come and have a good time on the Riviera despite the coronavirus epidemic.Everything had been planned by the organiser of the trip...starting with the London-Marseille trip in a private jet that he had rented on the other side of the Channel.He then booked a luxury villa in Cannes. To get there, the man had reserved three helicopters from a company which provides private connections for privileged customers.Commercial flights are greatly reduced at airports across Europe at the moment, and the authorities are trying to stop private jets breaking restrictions.The source reported that police guarding the borders of Marseille-Provence airport asked the private jet not to come and land on its tarmac.But the plane still landed anyway, and the passengers were not allowed to leave the aircraft.The private jet used by the groups was an Embraer Legacy - a Brazilian made luxury business jet.Controlled by the border police and the gendarmerie of air transport, none had valid reasons for traveling, said the source.Crossing borders is only allowed with a legitimate or compelling reason.As well as Croatian, the other travellers were German, French, Romanian and Ukrainian, said the source.They initially argued with police, and expressed anger when three helicopters waiting for them were ordered to leave empty, and their pilots fined for breaking lockdown restrictions.The source said the Croatian had paid for everything, including the villa and plane, was  looking forward to the break, with his friends and young female escorts.When confronted by police, he offered them cash, saying: ‘I have money, let’s talk,’ said the police source.The source added: He said they all go to the villa, and lockdown there, and that there would be no problem.But it was obviously a recreational trip, and under the containment measures these are strictly prohibited.’The only fines issued were to the three French helicopter pilots.None of those on board have yet been identied by police.Nine members of the holiday party ed to London by the private jet on Saturday evening, while the tenth went back to Germany.France has been in lockdown since March  in a bid to slow the spread of the pandemic, with only essential trips allowed that must be justied with a signed piece of paper.Health director Jérôme Salomon said the lockdown was working: ‘Thanks to these measures, we are in the process of putting the brakes on the epidemic.’The lockdown, which was supposed to run until April , will be extended beyond that date, it was announced on Wednesday.President Emmanuel Macron will discuss the coronavirus situation in a live TV address to the nation on Monday.     Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus lockdown exhausted vivid dreams sleep
story: WITH the pubs closed and daily commutes cancelled, most of us have no excuse for not getting enough sleep. But many people have reported feeling exhausted during the day and finding it harder to wake up in the morning.Others have reported experiencing vivid and disturbing dreams - or remembering them really clearly when they wake up.Experts explain that its likely that the changes to our everyday lives are having an impact on our circadian rhythms.Otherwise, known as the bodys inner clock, these -hour cycles dictate everything - from when we feel sleepy to when our immune cells are most active.Professor Colin A Espie, Professor of Sleep Medicine at Oxford University, told Sky News: Sleep is central to our lives and because it happens automatically we take it for granted.Now we are in one place [most of the day] it is easy for sleep and wakefulness to merge.He said that this amounts to a dampening of our circadian rhythms and can make people feel fatigued during the day and unusually groggy in the morning.Natural daylight is also important to our sleep cycle - but by staying inside more and not needing to get up as early, its likely that this has had an impact, he explained.Prof Espie added: That loss of light and change of habit allows the body clock to drt and can lead to a sense of malaise.He recommended getting up at your usual time - unless it was very early - and getting dressed.For those who exercise outside, Prof Espie said its best to try and do it early in the day and make the most of the outside light early on.If not, even standing at your front door is enough to get that daily exposure.Prof Espie also suggested that getting into bed too early could cause problems so slip between the sheets just before you want to go to sleep.Also, use some low lighting in your bedroom just beforehand to help you drt off.If you cant sleep, get back out of bed and do something  for a short while before trying again, he said.But most importantly, he says you should simply try sticking to a sleep routine - and avoid having naps.Its easy to eat more than you need but its hard to sleep more than you need, he said.By sleeping outside of normal times, a persons sleep pattern will fragment and make it harder, with sleep often becoming lighter.Meanwhile, other experts have said theyve noticed an uptick in people reporting vivid or disturbing dreams.Dreams expert Jane Teresa Anderson told The Sun: “Most people are saying to me that their dreams are not only vivid, but they’re movie- dramas.“Often our dreams are more vivid when they’re more emotional.Dr Ian Wallace, psychologist and dreams guru, explained that many people are remembering their dreams more than usual.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealHe said: “Quite simply, many people are no longer waking up to their usual alarm - title: mild coronavirus symptoms toilet
story: IT may feel like weve known about coronavirus for a long time now - but its still only a been around four months.Scientists are still working to understand it but by this stage we do know the main symptoms - a new or persistent dry cough and a fever.But experts say there are a few other indicators that could suggest that you might have caught Covid-.And one of them involves going to the toilet.While there is no normal amount you should need to poop every day, needing more than usual could be an early sign of coronavirus.Doctor  U GP Dr Diana Gall explained to the Express: Digestion problems and changes in bowel habits - particularly looser stools and making more frequent trips to the toilet - are sometimes the first signs that you’re coming down with something, not just with this coronavirus.However, diarrhoea has been reported as an early symptom in patients who have later tested positive for COVID-.A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, analysed data  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and found nearly  per cent had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain.Isla Haslam, , from Balham, South West London, was someone who also experienced stomach troubles whilst battling coronavirus.She told The Sun Online that she initially woke up with a dodgy stomach, but thought it was from her dinner of lentils and beans the night before.But by the following day, she had developed a tickle in her throat and felt exhausted before attempting to rest at home.She explained: Waking up in the middle of the night, I noticed my nose was blocked and I felt horric. My body ached severely, I felt so heavy and was sweating with a fever.Doctors have warned that a loss of taste or smell could also be a sign of coronavirus.The British Association of Otorhinolaryngology, which represents experts in ear, nose and throat medicine, explained that an eye infection conjunctivitis may also be another sign.In a statement, the docs said: Evidence from other countries that the entry point for the coronavirus is often in the eyes, nose and throat areas.A study published in JAMA Ophthalmology found that . per cent of  patients with COVID- at a hospital in the Hubei province had eye-related symptoms - although further studies are needed on a larger scale.A number of people who go on to have coronavirus first report losing their sense of smell or tasteIts thought that losing the ability to smell or taste could be due to the virus destroying cells in the nose and throat.Experts say its something people can commonly experience after having other types of coronaviruses - such as the common cold.Prof Carl Philpott, of the Norwich Medical School at UEA, said: Coronaviruses have previously been associated with what we refer to as post-viral olfactory loss– this is smell loss that persists after a cold.There are many respiratory viruses that can potentially cause problems with the smell receptors.So far with Covid-, the smell loss appears to be transient but only as time elapses will we know how many people have a more permanent loss.Ryan Van Waterschoot ended up in hospital for  days with coronavirus, and losing his sense of smell and taste were the first few symptoms.Just a day after losing the two senses, he went from feeling tired to not being able to move in just one day, before his temperature soared and he was rushed to hospital, where he was given oxygen for five days.The -year-old said: I didn’t think I was going to make it out of the hospital. I thought it was the end of the road for me.Some people may experience brain fog, also known as mental fatigue, as another symptom of coronavirus.Its not been officially looked into as a symptom but its another indicator that those who have experienced the illness have reported experiencing.Thea Jourdan, , said she didnt experience a cough or fever - instead her introduction to Covid- began with a tickle in her throat and a dull headache,.The mum-of-three, from Hampshire, says she then started to experience brain fog.She told the Daily Mail: Initially I felt exhausted, asI was dragging myself through treacle and had no choice but to go to my bed. I had no meaningful cough and I wasn’t running a fever.But I had a peculiar sensation of something settling deep within my lungs, almost like breathing in talcum powder.I also had brain fog. I was unable even to fill out forms from the children’s schools. I just wanted to sleep.Another woman, who had recently recovered from Covid-, told the Huffington Post that she too had experienced the unusual mental block before her symptoms worsened.Christy, from Seattle, had a similar feeing of brain fog - she said her illness started with a multi-day fever that progressed into sinus congestion and a headache following it.She added: “It’s not just a cold. I’m pretty healthy and not old , and it kicked my a**.”Another symptom that coronavirus patients have reported is feeling extremely tired before symptoms develop.According to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association, up to  per cent of those hospitalised with Covid- reported exhaustion and fatigue.Linda Carr, , from Hethersett, Norfolk, told the Mail: I felt very sick and terribly fatigued. But I didn’t have a temperature or a cough.Within two days I could barely stand. I didn’t have the energy to lt one foot in front of the other.But she knew it was more serious than a flu when she developed a tightness in her chest that left her short of breath.After visiting her GP, she was sent straight to hospital where she was kept for five days after testing positive.Linda says she is still feeling weak and remains in isolation at home.Those who develop minor symptoms such as a high temperature or continuous cough should self-isolate for seven days.If you live with others, you should also stay at home for  days from the day the first person started showing symptoms.Anyone with suspected coronavirus who becomes seriously ill should call  and in a medical emergency always call .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: peter vicar coronavirus family goodbye
story: A VICAR who would usually be leading Easter services this weekend is fighting for his le in hospital.Peter Holmes, , who suffers from asthma, has spent  days on a ventilator after coming down with coronavirus.He told The Sun: “We are hoping for a miracle. title: coronavirus lockdown wuhan mcdonalds queue
story: HUGE queues of people outside a McDonald’s in Wuhan have been spotted after the coronavirus lockdown was lted.Russian expat Darya Kuznetsova, who lives in Wuhan in the eastern Chinese province of Hubei, shared the video on her Instagram account.Filmed after the lockdown was lted following nearly three months of strict quarantine, the footage shows a long queue of people, all apparently wearing face masks, filing out of a McDonald’s restaurant and onto the pavement.According to Darya, the McDonald’s restaurant has become the most popular place in the city and has been mobbed ever since people were first let outside.She said: “McDonald’s is now the busiest place in the city. story: IRELAND is extending its lockdown until May , while England remains in limbo on when theirs will be lted.Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has announced today the current restrictions on movement in title: who is priti patel home secretary coronavirus response
story: The Home Secretary finally spoke publicly for the first time since the coronavirus crisis began in the UK on Friday, April  when she blasted a top cop for his over the top response to enforcing the lockdown. Heres what we know.Priti Patel came under criticism for refusing to appear in front of a select committee to discuss the coronavirus outbreak in April, .She had turned down four invitations to appear before the Home Affairs Committee since January but had been offering private briefings.Priti defended herself in an interview with The Sun’s Executive Editor Dan Wootton during this talkRADIO Drivetime show on April .In her first interview since the UK went into lockdown, she accused Labour MP Yvette Cooper of playing politics and insisted she had given Cooper a date to appear in front of the Home Affairs Select Committee.Since she was appointed Home Secretary in July  she has only appeared in front of the committee once.Patel has not appeared at any of the Governments daily coronavirus press briefings sparking suggestions from some she may have been sidelined because she was a woman.She broke her silence to blast Northamptonshire’s Chief Constable Nick Adderley over his threat to snoop on the British public’s shopping baskets during the coronavirus lockdown.In a press conference he warned officers would stop and search trolliesthe public ignored lockdown measures.The police threat was not appropriate and wasnt part of the governments guidance, she told Wootton.She urged Brits to adhere to the lockdown over the Easter weekend and praised the public for their reaction to measures put in place by the government so farShe said the government was considering new measures to help domestic violence victims who were stuck in lockdown with their abusive partners and confirmed she would be laying out the plans next week.And said there had been an increase in threats to the public from online fraudsters since the beginning of the pandemic.Prime Minister Boris Johns appointed Priti Patel to the role of Home Secretary on July , , replacing Sajid Javid, who was promoted to Chancellor.She is a Conservative MP who has served the Witham constituency in Essex since .The -year-old Brexiteer was forced to resign as International Development Secretary in November  after holding  secret meetings in Israel without following protocol.Priti is a long-standing supporter of Israel and a former vice-chairman of CFI.Born in London to a Ugandan Indian migrant family and educated at a comprehensive school in Watford, Patel went on to study economics at Keele University before completing her postgraduate studies at the University of Essex.In , Priti was appointed as Exchequer Secretary to the Treasury and following the  General Election was appointed as the new Minister for Employment at the Department for Work and Pensions.A longstanding Eurosceptic, Patel was a leading figure in the Vote Leave campaign during the  EU referendum.Following David Camerons resignation, Patel backed PM Theresa May who subsequently appointed her as International Development Secretary in the summer of .Priti Patel told the Tory party conference in October , the government would introduce an Australian-style points system that works in the best interests of Britain.Reiterating the hard-line immigration pledge in Manchester, Ms Patel said: I have a particular responsibility when it comes to taking back control.It is to end the free movement of people once and for all.Instead we will introduce an Australian style points-based immigration system.One that works in the best interests of Britain.Ms Patel also announced a £million fund to tackle county lines drugs gangs to stop them “terrorising” Britain’s kids.The meetings in Israel were held between August  and ,  while Patel was on holiday with her family.The Department for International Developmentrevealed that Patel held  meetings in  days including Benjamin Netanyahu, Gilad Erdan, the public security minister and Yair Lapid, leader of Israel’s centrist Yesh Atid party, without telling the foreign office in advance.But she insisted that her trip had “nothing to do with foreign policy” saying the trip was “a family holiday paid for myself”, but admitted that, on ing, she had “commissioned departmental work on humanitarian and development partnership between Israel and the UK, and on disability”.The meetings were arranged by Lord Polack, the honorary president of the lobbying group Conservative Friends of Israel - and UK government policy toward the Middle East ally was reportedly discussed.Patel did not tell the Foreign Office before meeting with Israeli prime minister and other politicians, businesses and charities.She appeared to have avoided the sack over the trip after admitting she had shown a “lack of precision” over the wording she used on Friday when she suggested that Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson knew about it in advance.She conceded that Boris was not told in advance and that she held  meetings rather than the two originally reported.The revelations emerged while the Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is in London this week to mark the centenary of the Balfour Declaration when Britain first gave its support for a national home for the Jewish people.A spokesman for Patel said: “The Foreign Office are clear that UK interests were not damaged or affected by the meetings on this visit.”In his memoir For The Record, David Cameron criticised Priti Patels role in the Brexit referendum campaign.He accused her of using every announcement, interview and speech to hammer the governments approach to immigration, even though she was in it.But he said that he was stuck with her in his administration becausehe fired her she would become a Brexit martyr.Patel has since brushed off his comments, saying: There is no point in going over the past.Obviously the referendum has happened, we have moved on and the fact of the matter is we are now working to deliver that referendum mandate.That is so important. There is no point in going over the past.

title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams revealed in April  that it was continuing with plans set before it went into administration to close  stores in .As a result of falling into administration again in April , it also decided to axe all  of its shops in Ireland.It had previously closed  stores in January , including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Weve asked Debenhams how many stores its closed in total over the past few years and well update this story as soon as we get a response.Debenhams told us the exact locations of the  stores set to close next year are still to be determined.It currently has  shops remaining.Debenhams went into administration in April .Its the second time the department store chain has gone bust in a year and also follows a company voluntary arrangement- a type of insolvency process.Debenhams has appointed business advisory firm FRP Advisory to oversee the process.The -year-old retailer last entered administration in April .Back then, lenders took control of the struggling retailer which wiped out the investments of shareholders, including Sports Direct billionaire Mike Ashley.But stores remained open and the retailer says this time round it will work to re-open and trade as many stores as possible when coronavirus related lockdown restrictions are lted.Debenhams website is currently trading as normal and it even has a half price Easter sale on.Customers are still able to spend their gt cards online and in storesas normal.But shoppers might want to consider using any gt cards they have while the retailer is still accepting them.Debenhams points out that online, you can only use one gt card per transaction.Returns are still being accepted as usual.But again, you might want to consider ing or exchanging items sooner rather than later to be on the safe side - thatsyoure able to do so safely during lockdown.You should also consider putting new purchases on credit card as this will give you greater protectionsomething goes wrong with the purchase and youre unable to get your money back from Debenhams.Debit card purchases also offer some protection, but not to the same extent as those offered by credit cards.

title: pressure to end coronavirus lockdown
story: Ministers are reluctant to lt the strict measures despite experts claiming that Brits “cannot hide away forever”.Dominic Raab – filling in for Boris Johnson - warned yesterday it was still too early for social distancing to be lted.And epidemiologist Professor Neil Ferguson, of Imperial College London, said “definitive” proof of whether the nationwide-lockdown has worked will take “several more weeks”.He explained: “It is only when we see the case numbers come down and how quickly transmissions have been reduced we can really conclude anything about what happens next, when these measures can be relaxed”.It is believed that less than  per cent of the population has had the virus and Mr Raab said that discussing a route out of lockdown would be a “distraction”.Scientists are still struggling to identy how restrictions could be eased without causing more harm to the public, the Times reports.But Rupert Shute, the deputy scientic adviser at the Home Office, warned yesterday that  per cent of the population will eventually get Covid-.He added said that while staying at home was important “we also have to keep ing our lives”.Mr Shute told the BBC: “You are no more at risk at the workplace than you would be in your home or at the supermarket. title: coronavirus infections finally starting level
story: NewsCoronavirus infections finally starting to level off - but lockdown must continueSources tell the Mirror they now believe Brits with Covid- are infecting less than one person each. But that doesnt mean restrictions will be ltedShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  APR NewsSources believe the crucial R number has fallen below  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus infections are levelling off as Britain is finally starting to flatten the curve. New infections have slowed and Government officials are now confident lockdown is working - but needs to continue to avoid collapsing the NHS. Sources say they now believe Brits with Covid- are infecting on average less than one person each. This is the crucial reproduction numberthreshold which,maintained, would see the outbreak slowly die out. New daily confirmed cases fell to , yesterday down from , the previous day. This had been falling with , on Tuesday, , on Monday, down from the peak of , on Sunday. However, deaths could continue to rise for a considerable period of time because they lag behind newly-diagnosed infections, and take time to be officially recorded.  Experts say this overall pattern shows we are “flattening the curve” - which was stricken PM Boris Johnson ’s mantra before he himself was hospitalised with Covid-.Lockdown was initiated based on Government modelling showing the reproduction numberwas between  and .. This meant cases were doubling every four or five days. A senior source leading Britain’s response to the Covid- crisis said: “If the R goes below , the epidemic just dies out anyway, which is hopefully what’s happening at the moment. “I mean with social distancing that we have now you would expect it to be around .. If we could stay like this it would be fine, it would just go. “If the R is somewhat above  you can still control it with active measures.”  Daily testing is now eventually starting to be increased to around , after stalling at around the , a day mark. Sources suggest lting lockdown measures could potentially be considered from next monththe Government meets its , a day testing target. That could only happensocial distancing has been maintained and hospitals are well within capacity. Prof James Naismith, biology expert at Oxford University, said: “There is now evidence that social distancing measures are having the expected effect. “Fewer people are getting infected which means fewer people will need intensive care which means fewer people will die.  “The lockdown has some weeks to run to bring down the number of infections and reduce pressure on the NHS.

Last week May spoke out in support of Boris Johnson who remains in hospital at St Thomasapos Hospital in London - although has now left intensive care. She said: My thoughts and prayers are with Boris Johnson and his family as he continues to receive treatment in hospital . Follow all coronavirus updates here on our live blog Outside the Waitrose branch, a number of cordons appeared to be in place, seemingly aimed at stopping people from crowding outside the store. All supermarkets continue to impose social distancing measures for shoppers, allowing only a certain number of shoppers in at any one time. They are also enforcing similar measures inside their stores at till points. Now, as the country approaches what looks to be a glorious Easter weekend, the government has issued a number of warnings for people to stay home and save lives, despite the sunny weather. The military and police may also take to patrolling beaches and beauty spots to ensure people are not gathering. One police chief even warned his force was only “a few days away” from imposing roadblocks.  The Devon  Cornwall force also said it would be patrolling the M motorway on the Somerset and Devon border to keep tourists away from the area. Military Defence Police, based in Portsmouth and Plymouth, will be operating along the coastlines in Dorset, Devon and Cornall to ensure people aposdo not gather unnecessarilyapos,  reported i news  on Thursday evening. Foreign Secretary  Dominic Raab, standing in for the Prime Minister, urged restraint amid signs social-distancing was beginning to work. It comes as Boris Johnson  was last night moved back to the ward at St Thomas’ Hospital in South London after his condition improved following three anxious nights in intensive care. A No spokesman said the PM “will receive close monitoring” and was “in extremely good spirits”.  The PM’s fiancée Carrie Symonds broke her silence by tweeting multiple clapping hand emojis and a child’s painting of a rainbow, as the country applauded health workers at pm. Government officials are now confident that new coronavirus infections are starting to level off. But as Mr Johnson spent his fth night in hospital, Mr Raab said it was too soon to begin lting the measures brought in almost three weeks ago. Saying the Government would not even begin re-assessing the lockdown until the end of next week, he urged the public to think “long and hard” about the impact on heroic NHS staffthey ignored the rules.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailUK health chiefs are considering the idea of freeing younger people from coronavirus lockdown earlier than the elderly, two of the governmentaposs most senior advisors said today. Experts at Warwick University floated the idea this week - which could include reopening schools - because young people face a comparatively lower risk from Covid . Warwickaposs briefing paper, The case for releasing the young from lockdown, suggested releasing those aged - who do not live with older citizens, as the best approach to eventually lting the lockdown. Data suggested it could allow . million young adults to resume their daily lives, and shield society against an economic collapse. Medics and government ministers have made clear the lockdown will not be lted in any way for at least a few weeks, despite a review next week, and have urged people to focus on sticking to the rules. However, ministers are also facing questions about what the exit strategy will eventually be once the number of coronavirus infections starts to drop. Prof Paul Cosford, Emeritus Medical Director of Public Health England, today said releasing younger people earlier than others is being looked at. Asked directly about the idea, he told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: All those are sort of things that will need to be considered and are being considered. Prof Neil Ferguson of Imperial College London, who is leading government modelling of the virus, added: Without doubt measures will be targeted, probably by age, by geography, and we will need to introduce - in my view - much larger levels of testing at a community level to really be able to isolate cases and more effectively identy where transmission has happened. Medics have stressed that, while the risk of complications is far higher in the elderly, anyone of any age can fall seriously ill and die from Covid-. Prof Cosford said closing schools was an “important measure” to stop the spread of the virus, but said that despite some tragic cases, children are “at very low risk of getting serious complications”.  He added: “The importance of children’s eduction and children being in school is paramount. “That’s not the only issue, but I could conceive of circumstances in which some of the restrictions are lted sooner and some are lted later.” Asked directlyschools could open in a first wave of easing restrictions, he said: “Maybe. Some countries are looking at that. Other countries are looking at dferent ways of doing this.”  However, Prof Cosford also warned we have an “awfully long way to go” before any restrictions are lted at all, and “several weeks isn’t unreasonable. Let’s hope it’s sooner than that.” Ministers have also refused to be drawn on when schools could reopen, with few expecting them to open their doors after the Easter break and Scotlandaposs Nicola Sturgeon predicting they wonapost. All my experience dealing with any sort of infectious disease suggests once you start getting things under control, that is the time you absolutely need to continue with all your measures so you can bring the disease right down, essentially to crack it across the country, Prof Cosford said.  Professor Stephen Powis, the National Medical Director of NHS England, also suggested the idea was under consideration. Askedrestrictions could be lted by age and geography, he told Sky News today: “Those discussions are still taking place. There are lots of options being looked at.” But just like Public Health England, Prof Powis emphasised we shouldnapost expect any measures to be lted any time soon - and must follow the rules. He added: “This is not something that any country will be able to manage in a matter of weeks. We are going to have to work out a strategy and approach to managing this virus over months.”  It comes as Brits are urged to heed warnings that they should stay at home over the warm Easter weekend. There were encouraging signs on Thursday that the public were largely following the strict guidelines, with traffic levels showing an absence of a mass weekend getaway. The government has launched a publicity drive urging people to stay in their homes - including Easter eggs foil-wrapped with the words STAY HOME, SAVE LIVES.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UKaposs coronavirus lockdown looks set to be extended as Brits hunker down for the long haul. Drastic limits on leaving your home will be reviewed by April  - but itaposs clear they wonapost be lted. As coronavirus deaths continue to rocket, they will probably drt on into May at least. A meeting of the COBRA emergency committee today kicked off the process of working out what to do next, chaired by Boris Johnsonaposs deputy Dominic Raab. But the government isnapost planning to actually tighten the law - yet. Instead the focus will be on enforcing the law we already have and making it last longer.  Meanwhile police are preparing for a tough Easter weekend - with threats to search peopleaposs shopping and fine anyone going to bask in the sun. So what can and canapost you do under the lockdown law, what is changing, and when will it all end   Hereaposs the lockdown latest explained. What are the basic lockdown rules  You cannot leave the house where you live without reasonable excuse. That boils down to:Shopping for basic necessities, for example food and medicine, which must be as infrequent as possible One form of exercise a day, for example a run, walk, or cycle - alone or with members of your household Any medical need, including to donate blood, avoid or escape risk of injury or harm, or to provide care or to help a vulnerable person Travelling for work purposes, but only where you cannot work from home. Gatherings of more than two people are banned in public - unless youaposre from the same household, or a few other exceptions . And pubs, cafes, restaurants, gyms, funfairs, playgrounds, sports courts, cinemas, theatres, nightclubs, bingo halls, concert halls, museums, galleries, car showrooms, casinos, betting shops, spas, hair and beauty salons, barbers, massage parlours, tattoo studios, skating rinks and more must shut.  What is the punishment for breaking the lockdown  Breaking the rules above without reasonable excuse, or obstructing an officer enforcing them, is a criminal offence and you can be prosecuted. However, you can in most cases avoid a criminal conviction by paying a aposfixed penalty noticeapos issued by the police within  days. The law allows police to issue £ fixed penalty notices - rising to £ for a second offence and then doubling each time up to a cap of £. Police, PCSOs, council officers and other government representatives can also order or force you toto your home, and disperse gatherings of more than two people.  When did the UK go into lockdown - and for how long  The lockdown was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday  March. It took effect immediately. Police powers to enforce the lockdown took force a few days later - at pm on Thursday  March. The law says the lockdown must be reviewed by Health Secretary Matt Hancock every three weeks, with the first review by Thursday  April. But reviewing the lockdown doesnapost mean it stops. The law is in force for up to six months without the government needing to write a new one. Will the lockdown be extended for longer than three weeks  Yes. The UK government hasnapost made an official announcement because thataposll only come next week. But ministers, civil servants and  Downing Street have been absolutely clear that April  is much too soon to end the lockdown. Wales has already confirmed it will extend the lockdown. Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon added: I don’t think there is any possibility, any likelihood of these lockdown measures being lted immediately or even imminently. Even before a COBRA meeting to discuss the lockdown, Downing Street basically confirmed the UK government agrees with Ms Sturgeon.  Why isnapost the extension being announced properly today  Because the government wants to wait to see how well the restrictions are working at reducing cases. A formal announcement will be made on or before April , based on scientic evidence. Whoaposll make the decision  Technically itaposs made by Health Secretary Matt Hancock but itaposll be overseen by Boris Johnsonaposs stand-in, Dominic Raab. Not the PM, whoaposs in intensive care. Downing Street said: The Prime Minister is not working. I think weaposre very clear on that. And he has asked the First Secretary of State to deputise for him. It will be the First Secretary of State who leads the COBRA meeting [on Thursday] and the First Secretary of State who will lead any cabinet decision making process.  So can I go out for a picnic this Easter weekend then  No, absolutely not. Yes, the lockdown is being reviewed, but that absolutely does not mean it has stopped. You may only go outside your home with a reasonable excuse - just like any other day under lockdown. When will the lockdown end  We donapost know. But it will only be lted when the UK is well over the peak of new Covid- cases per day, and thataposs not any time soon. Ministers had hoped the peak would be Easter Sunday but estimates now put it at least a week or two later. Even then, cases have to drastically dwindle too. Otherwise thereaposll just be a second outbreak. The UK government has also repeatedly refused to say what its aposexitapos strategy is. Until we get a vaccine next year, itaposs quite possible they just donapost know yet. Officials havenapost ruled out a partial end to the lockdown, where some people can go outside earlier than others. Or restrictions being lted for a few weeks, then reimposed.  Are even stricter restrictions on the way  Not right now, no. The government hasnapost ruled out making the rules even stricter - such as banning exercise. But No emphasised the focus is on policing the current rules more strictly, not making new ones. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: I think the focus for now is ensuring that people continue to stick by the measures weaposve put in place. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden warned the government may enhance or change the lockdown, but thataposs not happening right now. No said: Weaposve always said thatthe scientic advice suggested other steps are needed weaposd be prepared to take them. But for now our focus is on ensuring the steps we already have in place are properly enforced. What does the law actually say  The lockdown is enforced through a law called the Health Protection Regulations . Importantly, it isnapost exactly the same as the government guidance. You should of course follow both, but it makes a dference to whether police can stop you going about your business. Here we go through a few common situations. Whataposs the full list of aposreasonable excusesapos for leaving my house  Reasonable excuses include, but it appears are not limited to:To obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies for those in the same householdor for vulnerable persons To take exercise either alone or with other members of their household To seek medical assistance To provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person, or to provide emergency assistance To donate blood To travel for the purposes of work or to provide voluntary or charitable services, where it is not reasonably possible for that person to work from home To attend a funeral of a member of the person’s household, a close family member, orneither are attending, a friend To fulfil a legal obligation, including attending court or satisfying bail conditions To access critical public services, including childcare school, social services, DWP services, victims of crime services To allow children with shared custody to move between each parentaposs house For a minister of religion, to go to their place of worship To move house where reasonably necessary To avoid injury or illness or to escape a risk of harm.When can more than two people gather in public  Exceptions to the rule are:Where all the people in the gathering are members of the same household Where the gathering is essential for work purposes To attend a funeral To facilitate a house move* To provide emergency assistance* To fulfil a legal obligation* To provide care to a vulnerable person** Where reasonably necessary. Can police fine meI exercise twice in one day  No. Government guidance is clear - you should only exercise once a day. You should follow this advice. But the law itself doesnapost specy how many times you can go out. It just says you may take exerciseyou need to. Meanwhile, guidance has been updated to let people with a medical need go out multiple times a day, for instance people with learning disabilities or autism.  Can police stop me sitting in the park  Yes,you canapost provide a reasonable excuse. You wonapost be surprised to hear the list of possible reasonable excuses does not include sitting, having a picnic or sunbathing - evenyouaposre doing it with proper social distancing. Police have of course been asked to show discretion, and there are exceptions in the rules for people with a medical need. Can police go through my shopping  The law isnapost % clear - but the Home Secretary has said itaposs not appropriate. It comes after a police force threatened to go through peopleaposs bags to check for non-essential items. After an outcry, Northamptonshire Police later claried: We absolutely will NOT be searching peopleaposs shopping trolleys in Northamptonshire. Home Secretary Priti Patel later said this is not appropriate and branded it heavy-handed. So thataposs all good. But what does the law say  The law says you can go out to buy basic necessities, including food and medical supplies. So you might interpret that asyou start buying non-essential items, youaposre breaking the law. But the government also says open shops donapost have to pull all their non-essential items from stock. So Sainsburyaposs can carry on selling, say, kidsapos toys and paddling pools - and thereaposs nothing to stop you buying them. Shops that are still open are free to sell any items that they have in stock, Downing Street told us. Yet Downing Street also told us: When we ask the police to carry out enforcement of any rules we give them discretion on how to do that. Thataposs the nature of policing in the UK. They have set out in guidance to officers that they should engage, explain, encourage and then finally enforce.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Coronavirus and lack of PPE has turned care homes into death trapsThe battle against the Covid- pandemic in the UK is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeriesShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionSeven residents of Hawthorn Green home in Stepney - which houses  people - have died since the pandemic started " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe priority in fighting the coronavirus has been to make sure the NHS has the equipment and resources it needs. Everyone understands the importance of supporting doctors, nurses and other staff on the frontline. That is why you came out in your millions again last night to applaud our  brilliant national health service. But the battle against the pandemic is not just being fought in our hospitals and surgeries. In the scramble to shore up the NHS, the Government appears to have neglected the half a million people in care homes. These residents are almost exclusively in the high-risk category. Yet care home operators say they have been ignored and are struggling to get the help they need. Many are short of staff because workers have had to go into self-isolation. Others desperately want personal protection equipment such as face masks and gloves. One home in Luton has reported that  of its residents have died and tragically there are more cases emerging across the country. Without urgent action more lives will be lost. We cannot allow these homes, offering comfort and support, to turn into death traps. Break traditionThe Easter break is traditionally a time for worship and for friends and familiesto come together.A time when children enjoy Easter Egg hunts and many head for the country or coast. With good weather in many parts, the temptation to break the lockdown restrictions will be strong. But we urge you to stay home.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs another Lent ends, I’ve finally begun to realise what it meant to spend  days in the wilderness. OK, I’ve only had three weeks of it and, unlike Jesus, I’ve been able to eat and drink, although Satan is tempting me every afternoon to sup unholy spirits. The gospels don’t say exactly what He did to kill time in lockdown in the Judean desert, but I’m guessing he pledged to do a lot of things, and failed. That’s my story. I told myself I’d re-discover books, but whenever I got a few pages into one I’d hear an alert on my phone, look away, spend half an hour scrolling, and realise all literature is doomedit exceeds  characters. I tried to learn how to cook something new to add to the one dish a week I make, but my paella stuck to the pan and I lashed it into the bin when one of the kids laughed and askedit was called a paella crap. I grew a beard, which I thought made me look a bit like Al Pacino in Serpico, only for my we to tell me I looked like Jon Pertwee in Worzel Gummidge. I decided to put a coat of nish on the rotting garden furniture but the three paint brushes I had were glued together with old paint, and when I drove to BQ, they turned me away because I hadn’t worked out how to click and collect from them. I never will. So I turned to Netflix, hoping to get hooked on a new American drama or documentary series and got so bored I ended up scouring US news channels to find a Donald Trump press conference for some mental stimulation.  And then a week ago I did something that finally beat the lockdown blues. I dug out my old DVD box sets and started to re-watch comedy classics. I devoured The Office, delighting again at Ricky Gervais’s glorious anti-PC creation David Brent. I stuck on Fawlty Towers and remembered how funny John Cleese used to be before he became a real-le whining malcontent. Watching the greatest political satire ever, The Thick Of It, left me marvelling at the master of the four-lettered insult Malcolm Tucker.

title: chris packhams wildlife lockdown animal
story: NewsChris Packhams wildle lockdown: Animal magic with Britains springtime mammalsChris Packham continues his wildle lockdown series, with zoologist Megan McCubbin, and tells us about British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and MayShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsChris Packham tells us about mammals to watch out for in Spring " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe might be in lockdown, but nature is doing the opposite at this time of year. Now is the time we can start to see mammals and their newborns pop their heads above ground. Today Chris Packham and zoologist Megan McCubbin talk about their favourite British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and May. Badgers  Badgers are active throughout the course of the year and would’ve given birth in February or March, so in the next couple of weeks the young might be coming above ground for the first time. But they’ve very shy. They live in setts in the middle of the large territory that belongs to the whole family. The main sett is where the badgers live for most of the year and where they rear their babies but they also have smaller setts which they use in the Spring, Summer and Autumn so they can sleep near to where they find food.  A family of badgers can have a really big territory - each badger terrirtory might have up to six smaller setts. They’re sociable animals and like living with each other and love to play. And they’re really good at knowing which territory is theirs by their latrines - badgers have really distinct smelling faeces which they put at the edge of their territories so other families know they shouldn’t enter. It’s quite a sophisticated set up and is essential to their survival. Bats  We have  species of bat in the UK,  of which are known to be breeding here - that’s almost a quarter of our mammal species. They’re emerging this time of year and you can see them in all areas - urban or rural. But bats are always betteryou’ve got water near you. Soyou’re near a pond, reservoir, anything like that, you’ll see they’re beginning to emerge regularly. Bat populations have suffered severe declines during the past century. Deer  We had a muntjac deer near us the other day. You can tell the dference between male and female because the males have two very distinctive dark lines down the forehead and have very short antlers. The females are slightly paler. Muntjac have these amazing curved bottoms like rabbits. They are quite pig like with very sticky legs and are one of my favourites. They’re not native to the UK and were brought here in  to Woburn Safari Park. Some of them escaped, which is why they’re quite common across woodlands in the south of England. They’re very shy and secretive animals, soyou get a glimpse make the most of it. They’re fascinating, you can see them on roadsides nibbling at the verges. But they aren’t too popular with gardeners because they go for all the tasty parts of your plants - they love rosebuds. Also just be waryyou’re out walking your dog in an area where they might be and keep your animal on a lead. Foxes  April is the time we would expect start to see our fox cubs and they start to move around out of their den. If people are lucky enough to have a den in their garden shed, this is when they’ll first see the fox cubs. They’re very unfoxy when you first see them, they have quite blunt faces with short ears. They look quite cat-like, like kittens the nose hasn’t grown down yet and they’re chocolate brown in colour, they’re not red yet. Wobbling about with their skinny tails, they try to find their balance. We’ve already had reports of that cubs have been sighted as early as Christmas and January. This is really early, which is a sign of climate change. Fellow Springwatch presenter, Iolo Williams, told me he saw very young fox cubs and that was just before or after Christmas. That’s quite unusual. Otters  Pre s, where a lot of chemicals were put into our waterways, many of them were devoid of le and it damaged the eco systems. Everything at the top of the food chain disappeared. Otters only really occurred on the western side of the UK, in Wales, Cornwall and Devon. When I was a kid in the s, otters were a rather rare animal they were dficult to see and it didn’t occur in Hampshire where I grew up. Now they have recovered their range and have been found in every UK county, all the way across from the west and now including Kent. But they have not recovered their numbers, so there’s still scope for more otters to exist in our environment, particularly now our waterways have been cleaned up. We can’t be complacent about otter conservation just because they’re back everywhere - they’re not back in numbers they were, but it’s great to see them turning up. In urban areas they have even been turning up and you can see them in daytime from footpaths. Otters were almost an enigma and now are mostly accessible. The Sainsbury’s supermarket in Andover has a path that runs alongside the river and while you’re pushing your trolley you can look over the side and see them. How to make a hedgehog house and highway  Hedgehogs are a favourite this time of year - everyone loves hedgehogs. It’s mild and now’s the time they’re coming out into the garden soyou have a trap camera, now is the time to set it up. You can also make a little hedgehog house which is really simple. Get a bucket, put some hay or straw, grass, any long organic matter, inside the bucket, just something the hedgehog can hide in. Lie the bucket on its side and keep it steady with something so it doesn’t roll. Put it under a hedge or somewhere not exposed – they’re very secretive and shy things and are much more comfortable when they feel secure.

Currently there is a daily delivery of a roll, cake, apple and crisps. Zane said: By delivering it myself I can check on vulnerable children. We donapost want children having to come out of their homes. The fewer people on the streets the less  coronavirus  there is on the street.I usually knock on the door and wait in the garden and can check they are being well cared for. It is knock, drop and leave, he told Grimsby Live. Other staff members deliver to homes in Cleethorpes, Immingham and Nunsthorpe by car. Zane added: The parents and children are pleased to see me and some have askedI could also do some shopping for them. Some are asking for homework, which I am happy to take to them. The former serviceman is a fitness fan and a member of the Cleethorpes Tri-Club. Last year he cycled , miles in two weeks in aid of the Cat Zero charity supporting young people trying to find work.
